column4: % of borrowers who are first-time borrowers with the FSP (or in the financial system)
column5:
This indicator shows the share of active borrowing customers who are new to the lender (new-to-bank/FSP) or new to formal credit altogether (new-to-credit, NTC). It is a direct barometer of financial inclusion and franchise growth. A higher share can signal effective onboarding and market expansion, but it also shifts portfolio risk: NTC borrowers may lack repayment histories, making underwriting more model-driven and subject to greater uncertainty. Supervisors and lenders can monitor this metric to balance inclusion objectives with prudent risk management and to evaluate the effectiveness of credit-bureau coverage. Definitions and concepts: First-time borrower (FSP scope): a customer with no prior loan or credit line ever booked by the FSP before the reference period. First-time borrower (system scope / NTC): a customer with no prior loan or credit line reported to the national credit registry/bureau within a defined historical look-back (commonly “ever,” or a long horizon such as 5–10 years). This indicator is obtained by dividing the number of first-time borrowers by the total number of borrowers. Variants of this indicator include: value-weighted (by origination amount), new originations only (versus the entire active book), and cohort-based analysis (by origination month or quarter). Data requirements: Customer master records with unique, reliable identifiers (national ID/tax ID; deduplicated across branches). Loan-booking history from the FSP’s core systems. Credit-bureau/registry match results (for system-wide NTC status). Product taxonomy (include/exclude credit cards, overdrafts, BNPL) and reference dates. Limitaitons and considerations: Coverage gaps: thin or partial bureau coverage, informal lenders, or non-reporting segments can misclassify NTC status.
Identifier quality: name changes, multiple IDs, or data-entry errors cause false “first-time” flags; robust deduplication is essential. Look-back window choice: shorter windows inflate “first-time” shares; disclose methodology. Product scope: excluding revolving credit or microloans biases results.

column4: % of all loans labelled as green or sustainable
column5: This indicator shows the share of a regulated lender’s aggregate loan book that is formally designated green, social, sustainability or sustainability-linked. A higher percentage signals that credit is being channelled toward activities aligned with climate-transition and inclusive-growth objectives, helping regulators gauge progress against national or international sustainable-finance targets and identify institutions with elevated exposure to taxonomy-related reputation or compliance risks. The percentage of green/sustainable loans remains a core barometer of how rapidly credit portfolios are pivoting toward environmentally and socially beneficial activities, and a leading input for green-asset-ratio disclosures and climate-stress-testing frameworks. Definitions and concepts: Green / sustainable loan: a facility whose use-of-proceeds (green, social) or performance-linked targets (sustainability-linked) satisfy market standards such as the Green Loan Principles (GLP) issued by the LMA, APLMA and LSTA (https://www.lsta.org/content/green-loan-principles). If a national classification standard is alreay in-play, this taxanomy should be used. The GLP require clear environmental objectives, transparent evaluation processes, ring-fenced proceeds, and regular reporting. Data requirements: Loan-level tagging for use-of-proceeds or sustainability-performance targets, mapped to the applicable taxonomy code. Up-to-date balances to build the numerator and denominator. Currency translation rates to consolidate multi-currency portfolios. Limitations and considerations: Fragmented standards: More than 30 national frameworks coexist, and self-labelled “green” loans can differ materially in scope, fuelling green-washing risk and hampering cross-border comparisons. Data immaturity: Many banks still retrofit legacy systems; incomplete tagging or missing verifier reports can understate true green exposure. Dynamic criteria: Ongoing revisions to taxonomy thresholds (e.g., the EU’s 2025 delegated acts) may reclassify loans ex-post, creating series breaks. Use-of-proceeds leakage: Proceeds must remain dedicated throughout the life of the loan; covenant breaches or refinancing can invalidate labels if not tracked.

column4: Value of insurance premiums writen in the insurance sector
column5: Premiums written represent the contractual revenue an insurer books when it underwrites new or renewal policies during a given period, irrespective of when coverage is provided or cash is received. They are the starting point for recognising risk exposure, funding claims, and calculating acquisition commissions, solvency capital, and market-share rankings. Rising written-premium volumes can indicate growth, improved pricing power, or inflation-driven sum-assured increases; declining volumes may flag competitive pressures or tighter underwriting standards. Supervisors compare premium growth with changes in risk capital, claims experience, and persistency to assess whether expansion is sustainable. Definitions and concepts: Gross premiums written (GPW): All premiums on policies incepted or renewed during the period before ceding to reinsurers. Net premiums written (NPW): GPW minus premiums ceded plus any reinsurance assumed—reflects the risk the insurer retains. Earned premiums: Portion of written premiums recognised as revenue in proportion to expired coverage—crucial for loss-ratio analysis. Single vs. regular premiums: Single premiums (e.g., lump-sum annuities) can distort growth comparisons with level-pay policies unless separated. Life vs. non-life split: Life premiums include risk and savings components; non-life premiums are generally short-tailed and annual. Data requirements: Policy-level underwriting feeds: issue/renewal dates, premium amounts, payment mode, product line, distribution channel, currency. Bordereaux or treaty schedules for ceded and assumed reinsurance. Adjustments for cancellations, mid-term endorsements, and pending reinstatements. Exchange-rate data for foreign subsidiaries consolidated in group reports.

column4: Value of insurance claims incurred by the insurance sector
column5:
“Claims incurred” represents the total cost an insurer recognises for claims events that happened during a reporting period, regardless of whether they have been paid yet. It is the single largest component of the loss (or combined) ratio and the primary driver of underwriting profit, solvency requirements, and reserving needs. Tracking the level and trend of incurred claims helps supervisors, actuaries, and investors detect price inadequacy, benefit-design problems, or emerging risk clusters (e.g., climate-driven catastrophes, medical inflation). Definitions and concepts: Claims incurred = Claims paid + Change in outstanding claims reserves + Change in IBNR (incurred-but-not-reported) reserves ± Claims-handling expense reserve movements.
Gross vs. net: Gross figures exclude reinsurance recoveries; net figures include them, portraying the insurer’s retained loss.
Basis of valuation: IFRS 17 and many solvency regimes discount long-tail liabilities at risk-free (or prescribed) curves and include a risk adjustment; local GAAP may use undiscounted reserves.
Accident-year vs. underwriting-year triangles: Actuaries analyse incurred claims development to estimate ultimate losses and adequacy of reserves. Data requirements: Detailed paid-loss data by claim, line of business, accident/occurrence date, and settlement status. Opening and closing reserve balances, partitioned into outstanding, IBNR, and claims-handling expense components. Reinsurance recoverables and salvage/subrogation estimates for gross-to-net reconciliation.
Large-loss and catastrophe flags to isolate one-off shocks. Exposure measures (earned premium, policies in force) for ratio analysis.
Limitations and considerations: Reserve estimation risk: IBNR and long-tail lines rely on actuarial assumptions; small parameter shifts can materially alter incurred figures. Claims inflation: Medical or construction-cost inflation accelerates reserve growth, distorting year-on-year comparisons. Catastrophe volatility: Single severe events cause spikes; multi-year averages or catastrophe-adjusted ratios give clearer structural insight. Accounting divergence: Discounting practices, risk-margin treatment, and expense allocation differ across regimes, complicating cross-company benchmarking. Timing mismatch with premium: Premiums are often earned evenly, while incurred claims can be highly seasonal; combined-ratio analysis mitigates this effect.
Used alongside premium growth, loss-ratio components, and reserve-adequacy studies, “claims incurred” provides a cornerstone view of underwriting performance and balance-sheet resilience. Limitations and considerations: Timing and seasonality: Large commercial policies often renew at year-end, spiking fourth-quarter volumes; moving-average analysis smooths this effect. Reinsurance structure: Quota-share treaties lower NPW without reducing gross market presence—analysts should examine both bases. Accounting frameworks: IFRS 17 measures premiums through the contractual-service margin rather than GPW, complicating trend continuity across adoption dates. Single-premium bias: High single-premium life sales can inflate headline growth while providing limited recurring revenue. Pricing adequacy: Premium growth is positive only if matched by commensurate risk selection and claims experience; pairing written premiums with combined ratios and new-business strain provides a fuller performance lens.

column3: Transaction accounts in areas with low density of cash access points
column4: % of all transaction accounts in the system that are located in areas with low density of cash access points
column5: A measure of the prevalence of transaction accounts that are inadequately served by financial transaction infrastruture. Overlaying the geographic distribution of transaction accounts on the geographic distribution of transaction points (e.g. ATMs, agents, POS) can help identify locations with deficits in transaction infrastructure. Definitions and concepts: Transaction accounts are broadly defined as an account held with a bank or other authorised and/or regulated service provider (including a non-bank) which can be used to make and receive payments. Transaction accounts can be further differentiated into deposit transaction accounts and e-money accounts, including mobile money accounts. Data requirements: (1) List of transaction accounts geo-located to the residence of the account owner at a primary or secondary subnational administrative area, (2) Number of cash-in/cash-out financial access points for each administrative unit at the selected sub-national level, (3) Total adult population (or surface area) for each administative unit at the selected sub-national level. This indicator requires first computing the density of cash access points per subnational area in per-capita or km2 terms and defining a threshold below which the area is considered to have a low density of access points. The percentage of accounts in subnational areas at or below the density threshold can then be computed.

column3: Deposit accounts covered by direct deposit insurance
column4: Volume and value (balances) of accounts covered by direct deposit insurance
column5:
This indicator counts (or expresses as a percentage) the deposit accounts that fall within the scope of an explicit, statutory deposit insurance scheme (DIS). It helps supervisors gauge how much of the retail/SME funding base is protected against bank failure—key for financial-stability messaging, payout readiness, and calibrating the deposit insurance fund. High coverage supports confidence and can dampen run dynamics; very low coverage may leave households and small firms exposed and raise contagion risk. Definitions and concepts: Covered (eligible) account: a deposit type included by law (e.g., demand/current, savings, time deposits); excludes typical carve-outs such as interbank deposits, securities, bearer instruments, and sometimes public-sector or affiliate deposits. Fully insured vs. partially insured: “Fully insured” balances are ≤ the coverage limit per depositor, per bank, per ownership category; “covered/eligible” may include accounts whose balances exceed the cap (partially insured). Ownership categories: individual, joint, trust/fiduciary, retirement—rules vary by jurisdiction and affect aggregation across accounts. Indicator variants: % Eligible accounts = eligible deposit accounts ÷ total deposit accounts. % Fully insured accounts = accounts with balances ≤ applicable limit ÷ eligible accounts. Insured balance share = insured amounts ÷ total deposit balances. Data requirements:
Core-banking ledger of all deposit accounts with product code, currency, balance, owner ID, and ownership category. Rules engine reflecting national DIS scope, limits, and aggregation logic (per depositor–per bank). Mapping to exclude ineligible accounts (interbank, affiliates), and to consolidate subsidiaries within a licensed bank. Limitations and considerations: Aggregation & identity quality: duplicate or inconsistent customer identifiers can misstate “fully insured” status.
Jurisdictional differences: coverage limits, eligible products, and treatment of foreign-currency and branch deposits vary which can mek cross-country comparisons difficult. Pass-through accounts: incomplete beneficiary data may undercount coverage. Dormancy: dormant or unclaimed funds may be treated differently in coverage statistics. Volatility: promo campaigns and quarter-end window-dressing can momentarily skew account counts and balances.
Pair this indicator with insured balance share, uninsured concentration, and deposit-stability metrics to obtain a full view of funding resilience.

column3: E-money accounts covered by pass through deposit insurance (or other)
column4: Volume and value (balances) of accounts covered by pass through deposit insurance
column5:
This indicator quantifies how much of the e-money customer base is protected if the issuer or its partner bank fails. It can be shown as a count or share of e-money accounts with eligible pass-through coverage, and/or the insured share of the e-money float (balances). Because most e-money models pool customer funds in safeguarded/escrow accounts at one or more banks, coverage depends on whether protection “passes through” to each named beneficiary. A higher covered share bolsters consumer confidence and limits run risk in stress events; gaps highlight operational, legal, or documentation weaknesses. Definitions and concepts: Pass-through deposit insurance: protection that extends from the custodian bank account to each end-user, subject to jurisdictional rules (e.g., per-beneficiary limits, record-keeping, and titling of accounts). Other protection mechanisms: statutory safeguarding/segregation, trust arrangements, guarantee funds, or private insurance that protect against issuer insolvency even if deposit insurance does not apply. Indicator formulas: % covered accounts = eligible e-money accounts with verified pass-through (or other) protection ÷ total active e-money accounts.
Insured balance share = insured (or safeguarded) amounts attributable to identifiable beneficiaries ÷ total e-money float. Data requirements: Mapping of wallet IDs to beneficiary identities and balances; status flags (active/dormant, KYC tier). Custodial banking details: account titling showing fiduciary/for-benefit-of status, participating banks, and deposit insurance scheme membership. column5:
This indicator quantifies how much of the government-to-person (G2P) payments ecosystem is protected by an explicit deposit insurance scheme. It can be shown as (a) the share of G2P accounts that are eligible/fully insured and/or (b) the insured share of G2P balances. High coverage strengthens public confidence in digital transfers, dampens run risk around paydays, and informs both payout-readiness and the calibration of the deposit insurance fund. Low coverage highlights legal or operational gaps (e.g., pooled wallets without pass-through) that may undermine financial-inclusion goals. Definitions  and concepts: G2P account: an account designated to receive social transfers, pensions, subsidies, or cash-benefit programs.
Covered (eligible) vs. fully insured: “Eligible” products fall within the deposit insurance scope; “fully insured” means the balance per beneficiary per insured bank does not exceed the coverage cap. Pass-through coverage: for pooled/“for-benefit-of” or prepaid/e-money models, insurance applies to named beneficiaries only if account titling and sub-ledger records meet scheme rules.
Indicator formulas: % eligible G2P accounts = eligible G2P accounts ÷ total active G2P accounts.
% fully insured G2P accounts = accounts with balance ≤ coverage limit ÷ eligible accounts. Insured balance share = insured amounts attributable to beneficiaries ÷ total G2P balances. Data requirements: Beneficiary registry with unique IDs linked to bank/wallet account numbers.
Core-banking (and, where applicable, e-money) extracts: product code, ownership category, end-of-day balance, currency. Rules engine encoding national deposit-insurance scope, limits, and aggregation logic (per depositor—per bank). Sub-ledger data for pooled/FBO accounts to support pass-through eligibility. FX translation and group consolidation for multi-bank or multi-currency programs. Limitations & considerations: Jurisdictional variation: some regimes insure only bank deposits; others rely on safeguarding for e-money—state the basis used. Identity & deduplication: weak KYC or multiple IDs can misstate “per depositor” aggregation. Timing sensitivity: balances spike on disbursement days; define the snapshot (e.g., month-end vs. T+2 after payout). Program design: joint/household accounts, agent-mediated cash-outs, or auto-sweeps to wallets alter insured status. Coverage caps: many G2P balances are fully insured due to small size; a few high-balance accounts can drive uninsured amounts—report both account- and balance-based views.

column5:
This indicator shows the share of funds sitting in transaction (checking/current) accounts that are not actively used by customers. High concentrations of idle balances can signal weak customer engagement, poor product fit, or frictions in account usage—important for financial-inclusion quality, liquidity management, and conduct risk. From a prudential angle, large dormant balances may look “stable” but can reverse if reactivation drives or policy changes prompt withdrawals. For consumer protection, persistent dormancy raises risks around unclaimed funds, fees, and fraud. Definitions and concepts: Transaction accounts: demand/current accounts and other payment-capable deposit accounts. Inactive account: no customer-initiated debit/credit (card use, cash withdrawal/deposit, transfer) for a defined window (e.g., ≥90 or 180 days). System entries (interest, fees, bank corrections) don’t count. Dormant account: extended inactivity beyond a longer threshold (commonly ≥12 months) that may trigger special handling (restricted access, outreach, escheatment). Indicator formula: Balances in inactive + dormant transaction accounts divided by total transaction-account balances. Reporting the split (inactive vs. dormant) can provide further detail. Data requirements: Core-banking ledger with end-of-day balances, product codes, and last customer-initiated activity timestamp per account. Classification rules reflecting local definitions (inactive/dormant thresholds; treatment of standing orders/auto-debits). Ownership segment (retail/SME), currency, and insured/uninsured flags. Optional: outreach attempts, reactivation outcomes, and fee assessments to monitor conduct risk. Limitations & considerations: Definition divergence: thresholds and what counts as “activity” vary by jurisdiction and even by institution—state methodology clearly. Data quality: some channels (agents, fintech front-ends) may not update the core “last activity” field, overstating dormancy.
Seasonality & cycles: balances can spike around payroll/tax periods; use consistent month-end or averages. Policy effects: dormancy fees, auto-closures, and unclaimed-funds rules materially affect trends. Coverage scope: exclude escrow, trust, and suspense ledgers to avoid inflating inactive balances.

column5: Suspense deposit accounts are temporary holding ledgers used when a deposit‐related transaction cannot be posted to its final customer account because critical details are missing or disputed (e.g., incorrect account number, unmatched inward remittance, garnishment order). The balance of suspense deposit accounts aggregates the outstanding debit or credit amounts awaiting resolution. Persistently high or growing balances signal weaknesses in reconciliation, client on-boarding, Know-Your-Customer (KYC) data quality, or payment-processing controls. They can mask fraud, facilitate money-laundering layering, or inflate reported deposits, so supervisors view the metric as an operational-risk and conduct-risk early-warning indicator. Definitions and concepts: Suspense deposit account: a general-ledger account that temporarily records cash inflows/outflows linked to customer deposits until the entry can be matched and posted correctly. Ageing buckets: many regulators require stratification of balances (0-30, 31-90, 91-180, >180 days) to highlight items that exceed policy tolerance windows. Resolution policy: internal rule defining maximum days outstanding and escalation steps (automatic reversal, contact centre follow-up, compliance review). Net vs. gross view: some banks offset debit and credit suspense positions, but risk assessments typically focus on the gross absolute balance. Data requirements: Daily general-ledger extracts of all suspense deposit accounts, with transaction identifiers, value dates, counter-party data, and original payment channels (ACH, wire, cheque, cash). Ageing analysis and reason codes (data error, KYC pending, legal hold). Reconciliation logs between core-banking, payments switch, and customer-account modules. Incident or fraud flags linked to suspense items for thematic reviews. Limitations and considerations: Accounting practices vary: some institutions clear items by moving them to internal “parking” accounts that may not be labelled suspense, understating the indicator. Offsetting distortions: netting credits against debits can hide gross operational exposure; regulators may require gross disclosure. System migrations: large IT conversions can temporarily inflate suspense balances, so trend analysis should incorporate project timelines. Regulatory treatment: in certain jurisdictions, long-dated unresolved credits must be escheated to the state or treated as unclaimed funds; failure to do so can trigger penalties. Regular monitoring—paired with strict ageing limits, root-cause analysis, and automated reconciliation tools—helps ensure suspense deposit balances remain transient and immaterial, preserving balance-sheet integrity and customer trust.

column5: A measure of the prevalence of transaction accounts that are in areas with a high circulation of cash. Overlaying the geographic distribution of transaction accounts on the geographic distribution of cash circulation can help to better understand the demand for and use of accounts. Definitions and concepts: Transaction accounts are broadly defined as an account held with a bank or other authorised and/or regulated service provider (including a non-bank) which can be used to make and receive payments. Transaction accounts can be further differentiated into deposit transaction accounts and e-money accounts, including mobile money accounts. While the overall supply of cash is determined by monetary policy that influences the level of currency in circulation, demand for cash concerns how the population chooses to spread currency across different activities, including (1) legal payments, (2) cash savings and (3) other transactions involving cash for use abroad, corruption or tax avoidance (https://www.imf.org/en/Publications/WP/Issues/2023/03/17/Measurement-and-Use-of-Cash-by-Half-the-Worlds-Population-531077). The demand for cash can be proxied by the aggregate volume of cash withdrawals. Inactive (or dormant) accounts refers to an account that has not been used to conduct transactions (e.g. deposits, withdrawals, transfers) over a long period of time prior to a specific reference date (e.g. one year). Passive transactions such as interest deposits are usually excluded. Data requirements: (1) List of transaction accounts geo-located to the residence of the account owner at a primary or secondary subnational administrative area, (2) Proxy for demand for cash: E.g.  total cash withdrawals over a specified period for each administrative unit at the sleected sub-national level,  (3) Total adult population (or surface area) for each administrative unit at the selected subnational level. This indicator requires first computing the intensity of cash demand in each subnational area in per-capita or km2 terms and defining a threshold above which the area is considered to have a high demand for cash. Among all transaction accounts located in earas with a high demand for cash, the percentage of thost accounts that are inactive can be computed.

column5: The restructured-loans indicator tracks the portion of a bank’s credit portfolio whose contractual terms have been modified to relieve a borrower in financial difficulty—by lowering the interest rate, extending maturity, granting grace periods, converting currency, or partially forgiving principal. A rising stock signals mounting credit stress and latent loss risk: while restructurings can help viable borrowers bridge a temporary shock, they may simply defer recognition of non-performing loans (NPLs). Supervisors watch both the level and the flow of restructurings to detect “ever-greening,” assess provisioning adequacy, and calibrate macro-prudential tools. Definitions and concepts: Restructured (or renegotiated / forborne) loan: an exposure whose cash-flow terms have been modified for credit-risk reasons and would not have been granted under comparable market conditions (Basel, EBA, IFRS 9). Troubled Debt Restructuring (TDR): US-GAAP term for modifications that result in a concession to a borrower in financial distress. Indicator formulas: Restructured loans ÷ Gross loans (stock measure); New restructurings during period ÷ Performing loans entering arrears (flow measure). Interaction with staging: under IFRS 9, most restructured loans migrate to Stage 2 (lifetime ECL) unless they are already Stage 3 (credit-impaired). Data requirements: Loan-level flags for modification type, date, and reason code. Original vs. revised contractual cash-flows to assess economic concession. Borrower financials to justify “ability to repay” assessment. Subsequent performance data (cures, relapses, write-offs) for back-testing. Comparable data on NPLs and write-offs to analyse migration paths. Limitations and considerations: Regulatory divergence: Some jurisdictions treat any concession as a restructuring; others exclude purely administrative changes, hampering cross-country comparisons. Forbearance episodes: Crisis-era moratoria or government-mandated payment holidays may inflate restructuring volumes temporarily, masking true borrower weakness. Ever-greening risk: Serial restructurings can keep loans classified as “performing” while delaying loss recognition; monitor repeat modification flags and eventual cure rates. Provisioning judgment: Determining whether a restructuring represents a significant credit-risk increase (Stage 2) relies on qualitative criteria that can differ across banks. Portfolio mix effects: High-yield consumer portfolios often show higher restructuring rates than collateralised mortgages; segment analysis is essential. Trend analysis—paired with NPL inflow rates, loan-loss provisions, and collateral valuations—gives a holistic view of credit-risk build-up and the effectiveness of loan-workout strategies.

column5: The delinquency rate tracks the share of consumer-facing loans—mortgages, credit-cards, instalment loans, auto, buy-now-pay-later, qualifying SMEs—that have fallen past due but have not yet crossed the “non-performing” threshold or been written off. Rising early-stage arrears are an early-warning signal of household stress and of future spikes in non-performing loans (NPLs), provisions and write-offs. Supervisors and risk managers use the metric to test the effectiveness of underwriting standards, collections strategies and pricing for credit risk. Definitions and concepts: Loan delinquency refers to a situation in which borrowed money is not paid back as agreed. A loan becomes delinquent when a borrower makes payments late or misses a regular installment payment or payments. When a loan is delinquent, the borrower failed to make their payment on time. A delinquent loan is any kind of loan that has past due payments but has yet to go into default. Data requirements: Loan-level payment history with “days-past-due” (DPD) counters updated daily.  On a value basis, this indicator measures the total outstanding balances past due (for example greaterr than 30 but less than 90 days past due) as a share of gross retail loan balances at the end of a specified period. Limitations and considerations: Policy relief: Payment holidays, deferrals or re-aging can artificially depress delinquency while latent risk builds. Portfolio mix effects: A push into unsecured lending will raise the rate even if segment-specific quality is unchanged; segment by product and risk grade. Vintage seasoning: Young portfolios normally show higher early arrears—compare cohorts of similar age. Operational cut-offs: Inconsistent days past due calculation (calendar days vs. business days, partial payments) hinders cross-bank comparability. Paired with NPL, restructuring and write-off metrics, the delinquency rate provides a timely, forward-looking barometer of retail credit health and provisioning needs.

column5:
Loan loss provisions (LLPs) are the expenses a bank records to cover expected credit losses on its loan portfolio. They represent management’s best estimate of future cash shortfalls arising from borrower defaults or deteriorating credit quality. Adequate provisioning is critical for portraying true earnings, maintaining solvency, and sustaining market confidence. Under-provisioning inflates short-term profits but erodes capital when losses materialise; over-provisioning can misstate performance and distort lending incentives. Definitions & concepts: Loan Loss Provision (expense) – the profit-and-loss charge that increases the Allowance for Expected Credit Losses (ECL) on the balance sheet. IFRS 9 three-stage model:
Stage 1 – 12-month ECL for performing exposures.
Stage 2 – lifetime ECL for assets with significant credit-risk increase.
Stage 3 – lifetime ECL for credit-impaired (non-performing) assets.
Coverage ratio – Allowance for ECL ÷ Gross non-performing loans; gauges the cushion against identified problem loans.
Provisioning ratio – LLP expense ÷ Average gross loans; compares flow of provisions to portfolio size.
Data requirements: Loan-level probability-of-default (PD), loss-given-default (LGD) and exposure-at-default (EAD) parameters, segmented by product, geography, collateral type and borrower rating. Macroeconomic scenarios (baseline & adverse) to derive forward-looking ECL. Historical cure, write-off and recovery data for model calibration. Management overlays documenting qualitative judgements (e.g., sectoral stress, emerging risks). Audited financial statements to extract opening/closing allowances and P&L charges.
Limitations and considerations: Model risk & judgement: Small changes in PD, LGD or scenario weights can materially alter provisions; transparent governance and back-testing are essential. Cyclicality: Forward-looking IFRS 9 rules can generate “provision pro-cyclicality,” with sharp spikes in downturns that magnify credit contractions.
Comparability: National GAAP banks (incurred-loss rules) or US GAAP (CECL) follow different methodologies, complicating peer analysis.
Management overlays: Discretionary adjustments can smooth earnings or compensate for model blind spots; disclosures should explain rationale and sensitivity. Macroeconomic uncertainty: In volatile environments, scenario design and weighting become highly subjective, increasing forecast error. Monitoring LLP trends alongside non-performing loan inflows, write-offs, and capital ratios provides a holistic view of a bank’s credit-risk resilience and earnings quality.

column5: The NPL indicator for the retail book quantifies the share (or absolute value) of consumer and small-business loans that are unlikely to be fully repaid. Because retail credit typically involves high volumes of granular, unsecured exposures, a build-up of NPLs signals mounting credit-risk costs, pressure on provisioning, and potential stress for both lenders and the broader financial system. The retail portfolio encompasses exposures to individuals and qualifying SMEs treated under the retail asset class. The most common ratio is Gross NPLs ÷ Gross retail loans; some variants net out interest-in-suspense or use Stage 3 gross carrying amount under IFRS 9. Data requirements: Loan-level ageing data with days-past-due flags. Classification status (performing, Stage 2, Stage 3, written-off). Outstanding principal, accrued interest, and collateral values (for loss-given-default analysis). Vintage or origination cohorts to distinguish structural vs. cyclic deterioration. Limitations and considerations: Definition drift: Some jurisdictions use 60- or 180-day thresholds, hindering cross-country comparisons. Write-offs and restructurings: Aggressive charge-offs or “evergreening” can temporarily lower the NPL ratio without improving underlying asset quality. Seasonality and relief measures: Payment holidays or pandemic moratoria may defer delinquencies, masking latent credit risk.

column4: Volume and value of written off retail loans as a proportion of total retail portfolio
column5:
The write-offs ratio tracks the portion of retail-portfolio loans that a lender permanently removes from its balance sheet within a period because collection is deemed impossible or uneconomic. It is a forward-looking credit-risk barometer: rising write-offs shrink the loan book, erode earnings through higher impairment charges, and may reveal weaknesses in underwriting or collections. Regulators examine the indicator alongside new-NPL formation and provisioning coverage to judge whether banks are recognising losses promptly or postponing them through restructurings. Definitions and concepts: Write-offs ratio is usually expressed as (Gross retail loan write-offs during period ÷ Average gross retail loans outstanding). Write-off: an accounting action that derecognises the unrecoverable portion of a loan’s amortised cost; it does not preclude further collections, which are recognised as recoveries. Retail loans: exposures to individuals and qualifying small businesses treated under the retail asset class for capital purposes (mortgages, credit-cards, personal instalment loans, SME overdrafts, BNPL, etc.). Distinction from charge-offs (US usage) is largely semantic; both eliminate carrying value. Data requirements: General ledger entries detailing gross charge/write-offs by product line. Opening and closing balances (or average) of gross retail loans, ideally split by risk segment and geography. Recoveries data to analyse net loss rates.
Policy documentation on write-off triggers (days-past-due, bankruptcy, collateral sale completion). Limitations and considerations:  Timing disparities: Institutions with aggressive 180-day charge-off policies show higher ratios than peers that delay write-offs until legal exhaustion, complicating comparisons. Macroeconomic overlays: Regulatory forbearance (e.g., pandemic payment holidays) may defer write-offs and understate latent risk. Portfolio mix effects: A surge in unsecured lending can lift the ratio even if asset quality within each segment is stable. Recoveries opaque: High write-offs can be mitigated later by recoveries; analysing “net loss rate” (write-offs minus recoveries) over the loan’s life provides a fuller picture. Trend analysis over multiple cycles, complemented by flow metrics such as “write-offs to new NPLs,” helps isolate structural deterioration from policy or accounting changes.

This indicator is a portfolio-level proxy for the all-in price actually paid by customers on unsecured retail credit during the period. It answers: How many currency units of revenue did the lender earn for each 100 units of average unpaid balance? Rising values may reflect higher base rates, heavier fee reliance (e.g., late/over-limit charges), or a shift toward shorter-tenor/high-yield products; falling values can indicate competitive pressure, promotional pricing, or relief programs. Boards, supervisors, and consumer-protection teams use it to benchmark pricing fairness, earnings quality, and sensitivity to interest-rate cycles. Definitions and concepts: Recommended numerator (topline revenue, P&L-recognized): Interest income (EIR basis) + contractual fees (origination, servicing) + penalty/default interest actually recognized + punitive fees (late, over-limit, returned-payment) − waivers/reversals. Denominator: Average outstanding unsecured retail balances (use Average Daily Balance - ADB). Formula: Cost-to-customer yield = Topline revenue from unsecured retail credit divded by Average outstanding unsecured retail balances. This indicator can be reported separately for interest, contractual fees and penalities if the data is available and when the period is less than 12 months, report an annualized figure. Data requirements: GL and product-level revenue broken into interest, contractual fees, penalty interest, punitive fees; flags for waivers/reversals and non-accrual. Loan/card-level balances to compute ADB, segmented by product (cards, instalment, overdraft, BNPL), channel, and risk bucket. Accounting policies: EIR vs. cash, Stage-3/non-accrual treatment, capitalization rules.
FX mapping for multi-currency portfolios. Limitations and considerations: Comparability: EIR vs. cash accounting and non-accrual practices differ; disclose methodology. Mix effects: more revolving/short-tenor loans inflate yields; always segment. Penalty bias: high ratios may be driven by a small cohort repeatedly paying fees—track % customers incurring penalties. Promotions/teasers: intro 0% and fee holidays distort short periods—show trailing-12-month and cohort views. Scope creep: exclude bundled insurance premiums or merchant discounts (BNPL) unless consistently included and disclosed.

column5: This indicator shows how much of a lender’s unsecured-credit revenue (credit cards, personal loans, overdrafts, BNPL) comes from penalties/punitive charges rather than from standard pricing. A high share can signal affordability stress and conduct-risk (fee-harvesting, opaque terms), create earnings volatility (fees fall when relief programs run), and invite supervisory scrutiny or caps. Used with delinquency and complaint metrics, it helps boards judge whether growth is sustainable and customer outcomes are fair. Definitions and concepts: Penalty / punitive charges (numerator): late-payment fees, over-limit fees, returned-payment/NSF fees, delinquency/default charges, collections/admin penalties, and (policy choice) the penalty-interest differential (interest above the contractual rate once in default). Topline revenue from unsecured credit (denominator): interest income (EIR basis) + fees/commissions directly attributable to unsecured products (excludes interchange on purchase volume unless you choose to include it consistently). Scope clarifiers: exclude origination/processing fees (not punitive), dispute reversals counted net, and stop-accrual rules for non-performing loans. Data requirements: General-ledger revenue by product with fee taxonomy (late, over-limit, NSF, collections, penalty interest). Loan/card-level flags linking fees to unsecured products; channel and segment tags. Adjustments for fee waivers/refunds, recoveries, and write-offs of uncollected fees. Policy notes: inclusion/exclusion of penalty interest; treatment of interchange; EIR vs. cash basis. Limitations and considerations: Comparability: accounting policies differ (EIR vs. cash; when penalty interest stops); disclose methodology. Regulatory caps & amnesties: changes can shift the ratio abruptly—annotate series. Mix effects: portfolios with more revolving/card exposure naturally generate more penalties than amortizing loans; segment results. Behavioural bias: high ratios may reflect small groups paying repeated fees—track share of customers incurring penalties and fees per affected account. Conduct risk: incentives to rely on penalty income can backfire (complaints, churn); pair with hardship/forbearance stats and early-arrears rates. For a fuller picture, report (a) the ratio by product, (b) customers affected (%), and (c) median fee per affected customer, alongside delinquency and write-off trends. column4: Difference between the average lending rate and a reference rate (e.g. deposit rate or external reference rate)
column5:
The interest-rate spread on loans captures the margin between the average contractual rate a bank charges borrowers and an external reference rate—typically the policy rate, the interbank offered rate (IBOR), or the yield on sovereign bills of comparable tenor. It is a concise gauge of (i) banks’ credit-risk pricing, (ii) competitive conditions in the lending market, and (iii) monetary-policy transmission. Wider spreads may reflect higher perceived borrower risk, limited competition, or funding-cost pressures; persistently narrow spreads can point to aggressive underwriting or excess liquidity that may undermine future asset quality. Definitions and concepts:  Loan interest-rate spread (simple): Average contractual loan rate minus Reference rate measured for new originations or for the stock of loans. Net lending spread: average loan rate minus average deposit rate, often used when policy benchmarks are volatile. Risk-adjusted spread: spread net of expected credit losses, revealing the “pure” return for bearing credit risk. Segmented spreads: calculated by product (e.g., mortgages, SMEs, credit cards) or by borrower rating to isolate pricing behaviour.
Data requirements: Loan-level or portfolio-level interest-rate data, including rate type (fixed / floating), repricing frequency, currency, and residual maturity. Daily or monthly reference-rate series (policy, IBOR, or treasury yields). Weighting factors (loan balances or origination volumes) to compute weighted-average rates. Credit-risk parameters (PD, LGD) if a risk-adjusted view is desired. Limitations & considerations: Benchmark choice matters: using a short-term policy rate for long-term loans introduces tenor mismatch; aligning maturities or using swap curves yields cleaner signals. Composition effects: a shift toward low-risk, collateralised lending can narrow the spread even if pricing policy is unchanged—segmentation controls are essential.
Regulatory caps or subsidies: mandated interest-rate ceilings or credit-guarantee programs distort market-driven spreads. Non-interest charges: fees and cross-selling income are excluded; the true all-in lending margin may be higher. Lag in repricing: floating-rate loans adjust with a delay, so measured spreads can under- or over-state current pricing in rapidly moving rate environments. Tracked over time and across peer institutions, interest-rate spreads provide insights into credit-cycle turning points, profitability dynamics, and the effectiveness of monetary-policy signals reaching the real economy.

column5:
This indicator shows how much of a lender’s net interest income (NII) is driven by penalty/default interest applied to delinquent unsecured loans (credit cards, personal loans, overdrafts, BNPL). A high share often signals borrower stress and potential conduct-risk (reliance on punitive pricing), and it makes earnings more cyclical—penalty interest collapses when hardship or forbearance programs are introduced. Boards and supervisors use the metric to assess earnings quality, pricing fairness, and the interaction with arrears and write-offs. Definitions and concepts: Penalty/default interest: the incremental rate (spread above the contractual/base rate) charged once an account is past due or in breach.Numerator (preferred “incremental” view): Penalty-interest differential actually recognized as interest income on unsecured products during the period (net of reversals/waivers). Denominator: Total NII of the institution (interest income minus interest expense). Consider a companion view using unsecured-book interest income in the denominator for a product-specific ratio. Recognition regime matters: under non-accrual policies or IFRS 9 Stage 3, interest may be recognized on net carrying amount or moved to interest-in-suspense—include only amounts recognized in P&L. Data requirements: General-ledger mapping that splits standard vs. penalty interest at product level; flags for reversals, waivers, and cash recoveries. Loan/card-level fields: DPD status, penalty-rate start/stop dates, base rate, non-accrual/on-accrual-resumption events. Period NII totals (institution-wide) for the denominator.
Policy notes: when penalty interest starts, cure rules, and whether capitalization is allowed. Limitations and considerations: Comparability: different non-accrual and Stage 3 practices; some classify penalty amounts as fees instead of interest. Collectability: accrued but uncollected penalty interest that is later reversed can overstate quality; track reversal rates.
Regulatory caps/relief: law changes or amnesties shift the ratio abruptly—annotate series.
Mix effects: card-heavy books naturally show higher shares; segment by product and delinquency bucket. Conduct lens: pair with % customers incurring penalty interest, complaints, and hardship/forbearance metrics for a balanced view. Should FSPs not be allowed/willing to share sensitive revenue data, ratios/percentages can be performed in-house and then shared with regulator.

column4: PAF as % of loan principal in unsecured credit operations
column5:
This indicator expresses the total up-front charges borrowers pay to originate an unsecured loan—processing fees, application fees, documentation charges—as a percentage of the loan’s principal amount. Because unsecured credit often targets price-sensitive segments and carries higher risk-based interest rates, excessive PAFs can materially raise the all-in cost of borrowing, undermine affordability tests, and trigger consumer-protection scrutiny. Tracking the ratio helps regulators detect predatory pricing, compare lenders’ transparency practices, and gauge competition in loan-origination services. For lenders, it is a barometer of non-interest revenue reliance and a lever for recouping acquisition costs. Processing & Application Fees (PAF): any non-refundable charge levied at or before disbursement for administrative tasks (credit checks, KYC, documentation, platform usage). Late-payment or insurance fees are excluded.
PAF ratio (simple): [Total PAF charged/Gross loan principal]×100%
Where multiple partial disbursements occur, use the aggregate principal amount. Annualised impact: when PAFs are capitalised into the Effective Annual Percentage Rate (APR), their weight declines as term length rises—monitor both absolute and APR-embedded views. Data requirements: Loan-level records capturing principal, disbursement date, PAF amount, and any rebates for cancellations. Product codes distinguishing personal instalment loans, credit-card cash advances, payday/BNPL equivalents. Borrower demographics and channel identifiers (branch, mobile app, marketplace) for segmentation. Accounting entries showing whether fees are recognised up-front (IFRS 15 “contract costs”) or amortised via the effective-interest-rate (EIR) method. Limitations and considerations: Amortisation differences: Lenders using EIR spread PAFs over the loan’s life; comparing ratios on a cash basis versus amortised income can mislead. Bundled products: Cross-selling (e.g., credit-life insurance) may shift income from PAF to commissions, understating the ratio. Regulatory caps & disclosures: Jurisdictions with fee ceilings or mandatory APR disclosures compress PAF ratios; cross-country benchmarking must control for such rules. Loan term effects: Short-tenor payday or BNPL loans show high PAF percentages even when absolute fees are small; interpret in context of maturity profile and APR. Waivers & promotions: Temporary fee holidays for marketing campaigns can distort time-series trends—flag promotional periods separately. Should FSPs not be allowed/willing to share sensitive revenue data, ratios/percentages can be performed in-house and then shared with regulator.

column5: The debt service-to-Income ratio,  sometimes referred to more concisely as the debt service ratio (DSR) expresses a borrower’s (or household’s) total debt-service burden relative to recurring income, answering a simple question: How much of each income unit is already pledged to repay existing debt? At the micro level, lenders use DSR to assess repayment capacity, price credit, and comply with responsible-lending rules. At the macro level, supervisors track average or distributional DSR to gauge household vulnerability to interest-rate shocks and to calibrate macro-prudential tools such as loan-to-income caps. Definitions and concepts: Debt payments include principal, interest, mandatory insurance on retail credit facilities;  Income can be defined in gross terms (pre-tax income (salary) plus verifiable recurring earning) or net terms (income after taxes and social-security contributions). Data requirements: Current loan statements or credit-bureau/registry reports detailing payment amounts, remaiming term, and interest rate for all obligations; Recent payslips, audited financial statements (self-fmployed), tax returns, and verified rental or pension income. Limitations and considerations: Income volatility: informal or gig-economy or commission-based earnings make future cash flows uncertain; Undisclosed liabilities: informal or unreported debts escape bureau coverage, understating true DSR. Household composition: shared living expenses and co-borrower support can distort individual ratios; some frameworks use household disposable income instead. Interest-rate path: fixed-rate loans keep payments stable, while floating-rate debt can raise DSR sharply when policy rates rise. Cross-country comparability: tax structures, social-welfare benefits, and healthcare costs influence disposable income, so identical DSR thresholds may imply different real affordability across jurisdictions.

column4: % of total premium income paid out as claims
column5: The claims paid ratio compares the amount of benefits and claims an insurer actually disburses during a period with the premium income it records for the same portfolio. It answers a basic question for supervisors, policy-holders, and analysts: How much of each premium dollar flows back to customers in the form of claims? Persistently low ratios may flag overly aggressive pricing, onerous exclusions, or servicing bottlenecks, while very high ratios can foreshadow reserve inadequacy, under-pricing, or a spike in catastrophe losses. In combination with the expense ratio, the indicator feeds into the overall loss or combined ratio that underpins solvency and profitability assessments. Definitions and concepts: Claims paid: cash actually settled with policy-holders and claimants in the accounting period, including partial payments and salvage recoveries netted where local GAAP allows. It excludes outstanding claims reserves and IBNR, which are captured by “claims incurred.” Gross vs. net basis: gross claims ignore reinsurance recoveries; net claims deduct them, better reflecting the insurer’s retained risk. Segmented ratios (e.g., motor, health, property) pinpoint product-level profitability. Data requirements: Extracts from the claims-management system showing paid amounts, dates, line of business, and reinsurance cessions. Premium registers (written or earned, depending on supervisory preference) reconciled to the general ledger. Catastrophe tags, legal-settlement flags, and large-loss registers to isolate one-off distortions. Limitations & considerations: Timing mismatch: annual premiums are often received up-front, whereas claim payments can lag; using earned premiums mitigates, but does not eliminate, this distortion. Claims-handling practices: delayed settlement or dispute escalation depresses the ratio without improving true risk experience. Reinsurance structure: quota-share vs. excess-of-loss treaties change the net ratio dramatically; analysts should review both gross and net perspectives. Regulatory definitions: some jurisdictions fold surrenders of savings-type contracts into claims, inflating comparability. Trend analysis should therefore pair the claims paid ratio with claims-incurred and reserve-adequacy metrics, catastrophe-loss disclosures, and expense dynamics to obtain a holistic view of underwriting performance and solvency resilience.

column4: % of approved/accepted claims that remain unpaid to customers
column5:
This indicator shows the share of claims that have been approved (final liability accepted) but not yet disbursed to the claimant. A high rate flags operational bottlenecks, weak payout controls, KYC/AML frictions, banking detail errors, or customer-contact failures—directly impacting customer outcomes and conduct risk. For solvency and liquidity, it signals accruals that have not converted to cash outflows and may point to reconciliation issues between claims and finance systems. Track alongside turnaround time, claims rejection/decline rates, and complaints upheld to get a full picture of payout effectiveness and customer fairness. Definitions and concepts: Approved / accepted claim: a claim with a final decision to pay (post-assessment), a recorded payable, and no outstanding dispute. Unpaid status: no successful settlement to the beneficiary by period end (or within a defined service-level agreement - SLA - window). Formula: Amount weighted (unpaid approved amount ÷ approved amount) reveal economic impact. Count basis (# approved claims not paid by cut-off ÷ # claims approved in teh period). SLA variant: % not paid within X days of approval (e.g., 5/10/30 days) to neutralize end-period timing bias. Treatment of partial payments: disclose whether partially paid claims are counted as unpaid or excluded. Data requirements: Claims-system fields: claim ID, product/LOB, approval date, approved amount, payment instruction date, payment method, beneficiary details, and payment status (settled/returned/pending/held). Payment rails & finance data: bank returns (RTP/ACH/wire), cheque status, e-money payouts, GL accruals, and reconciliations.Reason codes for non-payment: missing KYC, incorrect bank details, lien/set-off, legal/fraud hold, beneficiary deceased, sanctions hit, claimant non-response. SLA timestamps to compute “paid within X days.” Limitations and considerations: Cut-off effects: approvals late in the period will naturally be unpaid—use the SLA variant and report both snapshot and flow views.
Classification risk: some teams postpone “approval” until payment files are ready, artificially lowering the metric—define approval uniformly. Partial/returned payments: bounced or stale cheques, closed accounts, or rejected transfers require clear mapping (count as unpaid until successfully reissued). Reopened claims / appeals: specify whether reversals after approval are removed from both numerator and denominator. Segmentation: monitor by line of business, payment method, channel, and claim size to target fixes.

column4: Average number of days to process insurance claims
column5:
This indicator captures the average calendar days an insurer takes to settle a claim—from the First Notice of Loss (FNOL) to the final payment or formal denial. It is a direct yard-stick of operational efficiency and customer experience: shorter turnaround times (TATs) enhance policy-holder trust, limit reputational risk, and can lower claims-handling expenses. Supervisors use the metric to enforce fair-treatment rules, while actuaries and underwriters link it to reserving accuracy—prolonged settlement can signal documentation bottlenecks, fraud investigations, or catastrophic complexity that may keep outstanding reserves elevated. Definitions and concepts:  Start point – the timestamp when the insurer (or its agent/TPA) first receives verifiable claim information (FNOL). End point – the date the insurer issues full payment, partial final payment, or a written denial accepted by the claimant. Average TAT – arithmetic mean; many firms also monitor median and 90th-percentile to limit outlier masking.
Segmented TATs – tracked by line of business (motor, health, property), claim severity band, and distribution channel to isolate problem areas.
Regulatory service-level agreements (SLAs) – some jurisdictions impose maximum TATs (e.g., 30 days for uncomplicated health claims).
Data requirements: Claims-management-system extracts with FNOL date, interim request dates, settlement/denial dates, payment amounts, cause of loss, and reinsurance flags. Workflow status logs to pinpoint internal hand-offs (adjuster assignment, legal review).
Catastrophe identifiers to separate surge events from BAU volumes.
Limitations and considerations: Heterogeneous complexity: Cat or liability claims naturally take longer; aggregated averages must be risk-adjusted for mix. Partial settlements: Recording the date of first partial payment can understate full-and-final completion time. Dispute and litigation pauses: Regulatory or court‐mandated suspensions inflate TAT yet lie outside managerial control. Data quality: Missing or overwritten timestamps compromise accuracy; strict audit trails are essential.
Incentive distortions: Excessive focus on speed may encourage premature denials or under-reserving; pair TAT with reopen rates and complaint metrics. When trended over time and benchmarked against peers, claims-turnaround indicators highlight technology gaps, staffing constraints, and potential conduct-risk hotspots, guiding both supervisory intervention and management process improvement.

column4: % of policies downgraded at the customer's request (e.g.,  lower coverage, higher deductiblees, removal of riders, switch to a lower tier plan)
column5:
This indicator tracks the share of in-force policies that customers voluntarily reduce in coverage during the period. Elevated downgrade activity can signal affordability stress, product misfit, or competitive pressure (customers trading down to cheaper plans). It affects revenue (lower premiums), risk mix (higher deductibles shift loss ratios), and persistency (downgrades may precede lapses or surrenders). Supervisors and boards use the metric to monitor customer outcomes and pricing adequacy, and to gauge the effectiveness of retention strategies that preserve cover while easing budgets. Definitions and concepts: Downgrade (customer-initiated): a mid-term endorsement or renewal change that reduces coverage level—e.g., lower sum assured/benefit limits, higher deductibles/co-pays, removal of riders, downgrade of plan tier.
Exclusions: underwriter-initiated reductions, age-or regulation-driven benefit step-downs, claim-related restrictions, and administrative corrections. Formula (count basis): # policies with customer-requested downgrades in period divided by # active (or renewing) policies in period. Also report premium-weighted share using pre-change written premium for economic impact, and split mid-term vs at-renewal downgrades. Data requirements: Policy-level endorsements with: effective date, pre/post premium, pre/post coverage attributes (sum assured, limits, deductibles, riders), channel, product, tenure, and reason code (affordability, competitor offer, benefit redundancy, etc.). Renewal records to identify plan-tier switches. Linkages to subsequent outcomes (lapse, claim, complaint) for behavioural insights. Limitations and considerations: Multiple events: the same policy may downgrade more than once—decide event vs. policy-unique counting. Product mapping: ensure consistent tier/benefit taxonomy across products and vintages. Mix effects: shifts toward high-deductible plans can lower premiums and paid claims—analyse loss ratios alongside. Group policies: member-level downgrades may not map cleanly to master policy counts—state scope. Confounders: exclude automatic age/regulatory step-downs to preserve “customer intent” focus.

column4: % of claims logged by policyholders that are declined prior to substantive analysis
column5:
This indicator captures the share of claim notifications the insurer does not accept for assessment at the front door—typically during first notice of loss (FNOL)/triage—because they are clearly ineligible or incomplete. A high intake-decline rate can point to unclear policy wording, poor customer guidance, data-capture frictions, or overly strict gatekeeping. It is a key conduct-risk and customer-experience signal and, operationally, helps size avoidable workload versus genuinely assessable claims. Claim logged / FNOL: the moment a policyholder submits a claim or loss notice. Declined at intake (non-acceptance): the insurer refuses to open an assessable claim before investigation (e.g., policy not in force, peril not covered, waiting period, duplicate claim, claim below deductible/threshold, incomplete mandatory data not cured within a set window). Indicator formula (count basis): # claims declined at intake in period divided by # claim notifications received in period . Variants: exclude cured cases later resubmitted; report by product/channel. Data requirements: Claims-intake system fields: FNOL timestamp, policy ID/status at loss date, coverage/peril checks, deductible, mandatory-document checklist, triage outcome. Standardised reason codes (e.g., not covered, lapsed, duplicate, below excess, incomplete info). Deduplication logic (policyholder ID + incident date + peril). Linkage to resubmissions/appeals and to complaint records for outcome tracking. Limitations and considerations: Definition variance: what counts as “prior to analysis” differs; some firms place incomplete cases in “pending info” instead of “declined,” affecting comparability.
Gaming risk: shifting cases to “withdrawn” or “pending” to improve this metric; require audit trails and age-off rules. Mix effects: products with low deductibles or mandatory documents (e.g., health) have different baseline rates—segment results. Customer fairness: high early declines may reflect confusing onboarding or exclusion wording; monitor alongside claims rejection rate (post-assessment), turnaround time, and complaints upheld. Resubmission policy: disclose whether cured resubmissions are excluded from the numerator to avoid double counting.

column4: % of all insurance claims that are rejected by insurers (post-analysis)
column5:
The claims-rejection rate shows the share of claims that an insurer declines to pay—fully or partially—relative to the total number (or value) of claims submitted in a period. Because denial directly affects customer trust and complaint volumes, supervisors use the metric to monitor fair-treatment outcomes, detect aggressive underwriting or opaque policy wording, and flag operational shortcomings such as poor documentation guidance. A sudden rise may presage reputational damage, regulatory sanctions, or litigation costs, while an unusually low rate can hint at lax fraud controls or inadequate underwriting discipline. Definitions and concepts: Claims rejected (denied): claims for which the insurer issues a final communication refusing payment on contractual grounds (e.g., policy exclusions, lapsed cover, misrepresentation) or on fraud findings. Withdrawn claims initiated by the policy-holder are normally excluded. Partial rejections: if only part of a claim (e.g., an excluded add-on) is denied, firms disclose “partial acceptance” separately or prorate the amount. Segmentation: line of business (motor, health, property), distribution channel, and claim cause allow root-cause diagnostics. Data requirements: Claims-management records containing claim identifier, receipt date, decision date, decision outcome (accepted / partial / rejected), rejection reason code, and claimed amount. Policy data (coverage type, inception date, exclusions) to corroborate eligibility. Complaint and dispute registers to reconcile re-opened or overturned denials. Reinsurance flags to ensure ceded claims are not double-counted. Limitations and considerations: Definition divergence: Some regimes class “claims closed without payment” (due to missing documents) as rejections; others record them as pending, complicating cross-market comparison. Fraud vs. technical denial: Combining fraud rejections with contractual exclusions can blur very different risk issues—separate reporting is best practice. Volume vs. value: A single large, legitimately denied loss can distort amount-based ratios; analysts should monitor both count and value metrics.
Appeals and reversals: Denials overturned on review lower true rejection rates; timely data updates are essential.
Incentive effects: Over-emphasis on low rejection rates may weaken fraud vigilance, whereas strict targets can push staff toward technical denials—pair the indicator with complaint ratios, turnaround times, and fraud-detection statistics for balanced oversight.

column4: % of all policies up for renewal that are renewed
column5:
The renewal- or persistency-ratio gauges the proportion of in-force insurance policies (or premium) that remain active after a specified period—typically the 13th, 25th, or 61st month following issuance. High persistency signals strong customer satisfaction, effective servicing, and accurate underwriting assumptions; it underpins stable cash-flow projections, lowers acquisition-cost amortisation strain, and enhances embedded value. Conversely, rapid lapses erode fee income, accelerate reserve releases, and may expose product-design weaknesses or mis-selling. Supervisors review persistency alongside surrender-value payouts and complaint levels to detect conduct-risk or solvency concerns. Definitions and concepts: Persistency ratio (policy-count basis) = Policies renewed at month t / Policies eligible for renewal at month t
Premium-weighted persistency uses renewal premium divided by original premium to capture face-amount shifts. Cohort vs. calendar method: Cohort traces a single issue-year block through time; calendar aggregates all cohorts renewing in a given period. Relevant events: lapse (non-payment without value), surrender (voluntary termination with cash value), and paid-up conversion (premium holiday but reduced benefit) are typically treated as non-persistent. Data requirements: Policy-level records: issue date, premium mode, product type, distribution channel, grace-period status. Billing and collection feed to flag premium receipts by due date. Adjustments for reinstatements, partial surrenders, and top-ups to ensure consistent numerator/denominator treatment. Historical lapse assumptions embedded in pricing models for benchmark comparison.
Limitations and considerations: Measurement horizon: 13-month persistency suits annual-premium life products; short-tailed general-insurance policies need annual retention ratios. Basis differences: Premium-weighted ratios reward upsells and mask partial lapses; policy-count ratios may over-penalise low-value term covers. Seasonality & campaigns: Year-end discount drives can spike renewals, overstating structural persistency. External shocks: Macro downturns or regulatory fee caps can depress renewal rates; trend interpretation should control for such factors. Channel mix: Bancassurance and digital pathways often show different lapse behaviours—segment analysis is essential. Combining persistency ratios with acquisition-cost recovery schedules, margin analysis, and policyholder-behaviour models provides a comprehensive view of franchise quality and long-term earnings sustainability.

column4: % of lapsed insurance policies that have been re-instated after customer made back-payments
column5: This indicator shows the share of policies that lapsed for non-payment and were later reinstated after the customer cleared arrears (and, where required, satisfied evidence-of-insurability). A higher reinstatement rate can indicate effective retention outreach and product value to customers; very low rates may signal affordability stress, weak follow-up, or poor customer experience. From a risk perspective, reinstatements affect cash flows, reserve dynamics, and anti-selection (customers may reinstate when risk has increased). Pair this indicator with persistency, tenure of cancellations, and complaint metrics to diagnose retention quality and customer outcomes. Definitions and concepts: Lapse (non-payment): policy terminated after the grace period due to unpaid premium (distinct from surrender, maturity, or death). Reinstatement: restoration of coverage after lapse once back-premiums (and any interest/fees) are paid and underwriting/administrative conditions are met. Coverage may be backdated or resume prospectively per policy terms. Measurement window: define a fixed look-back (e.g., reinstated within 90/180 days of lapse). Formula (cohort basis): # policies that lapsed in period and were reinstated within {days} divided by the # policies that lapsed in period. Variants: policyholder-level (deduplicated), premium-weighted share, and calendar-period “reinstatements ÷ lapses” with a stated window. Data requirements: Policy-level: product/LOB, activation date, lapse date, grace-period end, arrears amount, reinstatement date, back-payment amount, underwriting outcome (medical/financial), and whether coverage backdated. Channel, geography, tenure at lapse, and prior claims/loan status. Cohort tags (issue or lapse month) for like-for-like tracking. Limitations and considerations: Window sensitivity: longer window raises the rate; disclose and keep constant. Classification noise: grace-period statuses mis-tagged as lapses depress apparent reinstatement. Anti-selection: reinstated policies may have higher subsequent claims—monitor post-reinstatement loss experience. Operational variance: some firms “rewrite” new policies rather than reinstate, understating the metric. Coverage basis: backdated vs. prospective reinstatement changes exposure and reserve treatment—report the split if material.

column4: % of eligible insurance policies (or policyholders) de-activated/lapsed that paid-out surrender values
column5:
This indicator shows the share of terminated policies that generated a cash surrender payout. It helps distinguish benign expiries or non-cash lapses from value-bearing exits that can strain liquidity, depress embedded value, and signal product-fit or conduct issues (e.g., early surrenders after aggressive sales). Supervisors and boards use it to gauge customer outcomes, the health of savings-type books, and potential mis-selling or affordability problems. Definitions and concepts: Eligible policy: contracts with a cash value (e.g., whole life, endowment, unit-linked). Pure risk covers (term, many GI lines) are ineligible. Surrender vs. lapse: a surrender pays cash value on termination; a lapse ends cover without payout. De-activatd here excludes natural maturaties and deaths. Full vs. partial surrender: count full surrenders tied to termination; report partial withdrawals separately unless they trigger de-activation.
Indicator (count basis): Policies terminated in period with a surrender payout divided by the number of eligible policies terminated (non-maturity) in period. Variants: policyholder-based (unique customers), and amount-based (surrender amounts ÷ cash values of terminated policies). Segment by tenure (<1y, 1–3y, >3y), product, and channel. Data requirements
Policy-level: product type, activation date, termination date, termination reason, eligibility flag, sum assured/premium basis, accumulated cash value. Payout records: surrender amount, charges/penalties, payment date, partial-withdrawal flags. Linkages for policyholder-level deduplication and channel identification (agent, bancassurance, direct). Cohort tags (issue year/quarter) for like-for-like comparisons. Limitations and considerations: Scope errors: misclassifying ineligible policies or counting maturities/death claims inflates the ratio. Early-tenure bias & charges: lock-ins and surrender penalties may suppress payouts despite cancellations—an outcome worth reporting separately. Reinstatements & policy loans: define treatment; loan offsets can reduce observed payout without changing customer exit.
Data granularity: partial withdrawals that don’t terminate cover should be excluded or separately disclosed. Conduct lens: high early-tenure surrender shares point to mis-selling or affordability issues—pair with complaints, persistency, and tenure-of-cancellation indicators.

column4: Average time between policy activation and cancellation, by chosen time periods (e.g., <3 months, 3-6 months, 6-12 months, etc)
column5:
This indicator captures how long policies stay in force before they are cancelled (or lapse mid-term). A concentration of early-tenure cancellations is a red flag for mis-selling, poor onboarding, pricing/friction issues, or product-fit problems. It also matters for economics: early lapses strand acquisition costs, depress embedded value, and erode persistency. Tracking tenure by product and channel helps target remediation (e.g., agent training, cooling-off disclosures, claim-time communications). Definitions and concepts: Cancellation: termination of cover before the natural renewal/expiry date—may be customer-initiated (voluntary), insurer-initiated (non-payment, underwriting, fraud), or regulatory. Activation (policy start): the in-force date (not the issue date, if different). Tenure (days/months) = cancellation date – activation date.
Buckets: choose stable, business-meaningful bands (e.g., <3m, 3–6m, 6–12m, 12–24m, >24m). Report count-weighted and premium-weighted shares. Scope: life and non-life; clarify whether non-renewals at anniversary are counted (usually not) and how cooling-off/free-look rescissions are treated (often reported separately). Data requirements Policy-level fields: policy ID, product/LOB, distribution channel, activation date, cancellation date, cancellation reason code, written premium/sum assured, payment mode, and claim history. Status logic to exclude simple expiries and to de-duplicate reinstated policies (see below). Calendar and cohort views (by issue month/quarter) to remove seasonality. Limitations and considerations: Selection bias: averaging only cancelled policies ignores still-active ones. For a fuller view of lifetime behaviour, complement with survival analysis (e.g., Kaplan–Meier) and standard persistency ratios (13/25/61-month). Reinstatements: define whether a reinstated policy’s earlier cancellation is (a) ignored, (b) treated as a separate episode, or (c) measured to the first cancellation only.
Reason codes matter: split results (voluntary, non-payment, underwriting, fraud). Early non-payment suggests billing/channel issues; early voluntary points to product fit. Channel & product mix: bancassurance, digital, and agency books have distinct early-tenure profiles—always segment. Cooling-off: report <30-day rescissions separately to avoid overstating issues that are procedural rather than structural.
