column4: Number of customer complaints (including processing status, channels, type)
column5: This indicator tallies the formal expressions of dissatisfaction that retail or MSME clients lodge with a financial-service provider (or an external ombudsman) about products, services, or staff conduct over a specified period and can be normalized by dividing by the customer basis to obtain an intensity metric (e.g. complains per 1,000 active customers). A rising complaint count can signal service-quality gaps, mis-selling, opaque fees, or inadequate disclosure—issues that erode trust and may escalate into regulatory sanctions or litigation. Supervisors can track both the absolute number and complaint-to-account ratios to test consumer-protection frameworks, prioritise thematic reviews, and assess whether rapid product roll-outs (e.g., digital lending, mobile wallets) are being matched by robust after-sales support. Where granular data or more detailed reporting templates permit, customer complaints can be disaggregated by processing status (e.g. open, in-process, resolved, rejected), product (e.g. consumer loan, deposit account, etc), channel (e.g. digital, phone, in-person), issue category (e.g. fraudulent or unauthorized transactions, unfair treatment, unexpected fees, errors on statements,  etc.), closure status (open, resolved with monetary compensation, resolved without compensation, excalated to ombudsman/regulator, withdrwan) or resolution status (e.g. favorably solved vs. rejected). Combined with resolution-time, compensation and other metrics, the number of customer complaints provides a critical, early-warning lens on conduct risk and customer-experience health. Definitions and concepts:  Complaints are expressions of dissatisfaction by (or on behalf of) customers that are related to their experiences with FSPs and can include any written, digital or recorded verbal statement made through any available channel, such as a branch, call-centre, email, social media, chatbots and other portals. Complaints may relate to the quality of a product or service, treatment by an FSP (including its agents and other third parties), or suspected wrongdoing. Complaints are different from general inquiries (e.g., where can I find an ATM?) or legal disputes between parties that may require formal dispute resolution. For more information, see for example CGAP's toolkit on using complaints data for market conduct supervision: https://www.cgap.org/research/publication/market-monitoring-tool-analysis-complaints-data and the Alliance for Financial Inclusion's framework on 'Complaint handling in Central Banks': https://www.afi-global.org/sites/default/files/publications/2020-04/AFI_CEMC_framework_AW_digital%20v2.pdf. Data requirements:  Database or log of customer complaints, detailing date of complaint and additional information, such as channel through which complaint was lodged, associated product or account, details or brief description of the complaint, and resolution status. Limitations and considerations: Complaints processes differ across FSPs in terms of steps/levels for routing, hand-over, escalations to higher management levels and to external ombudsman. Customer details and demographics of complainants are not always capture/stored on FSPs' systems, or may be stored in fragmented data bases. Complaints logged at aggregator sites/portals may not request customer demographics. Limited to officially logged complaints and/or maintaining records of inbound customer communications. Dependent on having electronic complaints management system.  Reporting culture: firms with easy‐to‐use channels may record more complaints than peers, even if service quality is similar—benchmark using severity and uphold rates. Under-reporting bias: vulnerable customers may forgo formal complaints; mystery-shopping and survey data can complement administrative counts. Duplicate cases: the same issue voiced through multiple channels can inflate totals unless robust deduplication exists. Product mix effects: complaint propensity varies—e.g., complex investments draw more grievances than basic savings; segment analysis is essential. Regulatory divergence: definitions and mandatory reporting thresholds differ across jurisdictions, complicating cross-border comparisons.

column4: % of customers affected by fraud
column5: Fraud directly erodes consumer confidence, trust in financial institutions and can trigger liquidity or solvency stress for institutions, tracking its incidence lets supervisors spot emerging threats before they undermine financial stability. Consistent monitoring also reveals control weaknesses, helping authorities direct enforcement, bolster preventive regulation, and keep the payments and deposit system trusted and resilient. This indicator measures the share of customers of financial services that have been victims of fraud over a specific period. Definitions and concepts: Several definitions of fraud exist and vary depending on the jurisdiction, local definitions of fraud for statistical reporting purposes should be used. For example, the European Banking Authority splits fraudelent payment transactions into two categories: (1) Unauthorised payment transactions: transfers made “as a result of the loss, theft or misappropriation of sensitive payment data or a payment instrument … executed in the absence of consent by the payer.” and (2) Manipulation of the payer: transactions “made as a result of the payer being manipulated … to issue a payment order … in good faith, to a payment account it believes belongs to a legitimate payee.” This definition anchors EU-wide fraud statistics and stresses both technical compromise (e.g., stolen credentials) and social-engineering scams (e.g., authorised push-payment fraud). Data requirements: Transactions initiated and executed during a specified period that are flagged as fraudulent linked to a unique customer ID; Total number of customer at the beginning of the specified period.

column5: Fraud directly erodes consumer confidence, trust in financial institutions and can trigger liquidity or solvency stress for institutions, tracking its incidence lets supervisors spot emerging threats before they undermine financial stability. Consistent monitoring also reveals control weaknesses, helping authorities direct enforcement, bolster preventive regulation, and keep the payments and deposit system trusted and resilient. This indicator measures the number of transactions that have been flagged as fraudulent and their corresponding value in currency.  Definitions and concepts: Several definitions of fraud exist and vary depending on the jurisdiction, local definitions of fraud for statistical reporting purposes should be used. For example, the European Banking Authority splits fraudelent payment transactions into two categories: (1) Unauthorised payment transactions: transfers made “as a result of the loss, theft or misappropriation of sensitive payment data or a payment instrument … executed in the absence of consent by the payer.” and (2) Manipulation of the payer: transactions “made as a result of the payer being manipulated … to issue a payment order … in good faith, to a payment account it believes belongs to a legitimate payee.” This definition anchors EU-wide fraud statistics and stresses both technical compromise (e.g., stolen credentials) and social-engineering scams (e.g., authorised push-payment fraud). Data requirements: Total number of transactions initiated and executed during a specified period that are flagged as fraudulent;  Total value of transactions initiated and executed during a specified period that are flagged as fraudulent.

column4: Number of operational disruption incidents
column5:
This indicator counts and classifies events that interrupt an institution’s ability to deliver critical financial services—whether due to IT failures, cyber-attacks, power outages, third-party breakdowns, or physical events (e.g., fire, pandemic lockdowns). Regulators track both the frequency and severity (e.g., service-unavailable minutes, customers affected, monetary losses) to judge the resilience of payment, trading, and customer-service channels. A rising trend can erode confidence, trigger supervisory remediation, and expose the system to contagion if multiple firms rely on the same outsourced provider or infrastructure.
Definitions and concepts: Operational disruption incident: an unplanned event that prevents or materially degrades the delivery of a critical business service beyond a defined tolerance (see Basel Principles for Operational Resilience, EU DORA, FFIEC guidelines).
Critical service: any activity whose prolonged unavailability could threaten safety and soundness or financial-stability objectives (e.g., real-time gross settlement, internet banking, card authorisation).
Impact metrics: duration, peak concurrent users affected, transaction backlog, financial loss, data-integrity impact, customer detriment.
Root-cause categories: hardware/software failure, cyber-intrusion, third-party outage, human error, environmental event. Data requirements: Internal incident logs with timestamps, incident IDs, systems affected, impact metrics, and remedial actions; Service-level monitoring data (uptime, latency) for validation; Post-incident reviews and root-cause analyses; External data feeds on utility outages or cyber threat intelligence to correlate systemic events. Limitations and considerations: Reporting thresholds vary: Some jurisdictions require notification only for incidents exceeding specific customer or duration thresholds, complicating cross-country comparison. Under-reporting incentives: Firms may fear reputational damage; robust audit trails and supervisory reviews are needed to assure completeness.Heterogeneous critical-service definitions: A mobile-banking outage at a digital-first bank may be classified as “critical,” whereas a similar disruption at a wholesale-only institution might not. Aggregation challenges: Merging data across subsidiaries and third-party providers demands consistent taxonomies and reconciliation of duplicate records. Trend analysis should be paired with forward-looking stress tests on operational resilience and assessments of third-party concentration risk to obtain a holistic view of systemic vulnerability.

column5: The early-loan-payoff (or prepayment) indicator tracks the share of outstanding loans that borrowers settle—partly or fully—before the contractually scheduled maturity. High prepayment activity can squeeze interest income on fixed-rate portfolios, change expected cash-flow profiles that underpin asset-liability management, and distort credit-loss models that assume stable amortisation. For lenders, rising early payoffs may flag aggressive refinancing campaigns by competitors, interest-rate declines that make refinancing attractive, or borrowers’ improved liquidity. Supervisors and investors monitor the metric to evaluate interest-rate risk, pipeline hedging effectiveness, and revenue volatility, especially in mortgage and consumer-credit books. Definitions and concepts: Early payoff / prepayment: any unscheduled principal reduction exceeding the contractual amortisation, including full settlement (loan closed) and partial prepayments (lump-sum curtailments).

column3: Borrowers in debt counselling and rehabilitation
column4: % of borrowers participating in debt counselling and/or debt rehabilitation progams
column5:
This indicator tracks the prevalence of individuals formally enrolled in debt-counselling or rehabilitation programmes: legal or contractual processes that restructure debt, impose spending plans, or provide financial-literacy support. A rising level signals household over-indebtedness pressures, tighter monetary or labour-market conditions, or aggressive credit expansion in the recent past. Regulators, consumer-protection agencies, and lenders track the metric to gauge systemic consumer-credit risk, calibrate responsible-lending rules, and anticipate write-off or provisioning needs. Definitions and concepts: Borrowers refers to resident individuals that have obtained any type of credit from financial institutions. Individuals are counted as one borrower, irrespective of the number of loan accounts held. Debt-counselling / debt-review: A court-sanctioned or regulator-approved process (e.g., South Africa’s National Credit Act, UK Debt Management Plans) where a certified counsellor assesses affordability, negotiates new payment schedules with all creditors, and disburses consolidated instalments. Debt rehabilitation / discharge: The stage at which the borrower has completed the plan, obtained a clearance certificate, or been legally discharged from remaining obligations (analogous to Chapter 13 completion in the US). Indicator forms:
Stock measure: number of active borrowers under counselling ÷ total number of retail borrowers. Flow measure: new counselling entrants during the period ÷ new defaults. Data requirements: Registry or court filings identifying unique borrowers, start and end dates, original and restructured debt balances, and counsellor accreditation. Credit-bureau data to link counselling status with credit scores, delinquency buckets, and new credit enquiries. Limitations and considerations: Coverage gaps: Informal or NGO-led advice services may not report centrally, understating prevalence. Regime differences: Some jurisdictions treat insolvency, debt management, and bankruptcy as separate processes; harmonising counts is non-trivial. Multiple enrolments: Borrowers can exit and re-enter counselling; deduplicating unique individuals is essential for accurate stock figures. Moral-hazard concerns: Easy access to rehabilitation might weaken repayment discipline; analysts pair this indicator with post-rehabilitation re-default rates.Privacy restrictions: Personally identifiable data are often masked, limiting segmentation by income, gender, or geography unless aggregated extracts are provided. Used alongside delinquency trends, restructuring volumes, and loan-loss provisions, the “borrowers in debt counselling and rehabilitation” metric offers a forward-looking lens on household financial stress and the effectiveness of consumer-protection frameworks.

column5: This indicator is a measure of the typical level of usage of instant/fast payments. Definitions and concepts: Retail fast payments (also known as instant, real-time, immediate, or rapid payments) across payment service providers allow for immediate fund availability to beneficiaries and can be used on a 'round the clock', 24/7/365 basis. Fast payments are payments where the transmission of the payment message and the availability of final funds to the payee occur in real time or near real time (For more resources on Fast Payments, see Project FASTT: https://fastpayments.worldbank.org). Data requirements: Total number of instant/fast payment transactions made across all accounts registered in the fast payments system over a specified period of time (e.g. quarter or year); Total number of accounts registered in the instant payments system at the beginning of the reference period. Limitations and considerations: With granular data, this indicator can remove the effect of different exposure times, by only counting the transasctions made over the reference period (e.g. quarter) by the accounts that were registered at the beginning of the period (and excluding transactions from newly registered accounts) or by calculating the exposure time for each account over the reference period (e.g. account-days).

column5: Remittances are an important source of external financing in many countries around the world and support the well-being of migrant families as well as broader development as remittances provide greater opportunities for savings, consumption and investment. This indicator measures aggregate flows of international remittances in both volume (number of remittances received and sent) and value (amount of money received and sent) using the country's financial insfrastructure.  Definitions and concepts: Money remittances are payment services where funds are received from a payer, without any payment accounts being created in the name of the payer or the payee, for the sole purpose of transferring a corresponding amount to a payee or to another institution offering payment services that is acting on behalf of the payee, and/or where such funds are received on behalf of and made available to the payee.. These could be inflow transactions into an account, but many remittances will not land into accounts, but rather be withdrawn in cash via a money remitter, a mobile money agent or a bank branch (Committe on Payment and Settlement Systems red book: https://www.bis.org/cpmi/glossary_030301.pdf?). Data requirements: Total number of international remittances sent/received over a specified period of time (e.g. quarter or year); Total value (in local currency units) of international remittances sent/received over a specified period of time.

column4: Number of deposits accounts
column5: The indicator tallies all active deposit accounts—current, savings, time, and other interest-bearing or transactional accounts—held at regulated financial institutions. At a system level it acts as a proxy for financial inclusion and the depth of retail intermediation: more accounts usually mean broader access to formal payments, savings, and safety nets. Sudden growth may signal successful inclusion policies—or, alternatively, aggressive promotional campaigns that inflate dormant or low-balance accounts. Contractions can foreshadow confidence losses, digital-wallet substitution, or macro-economic stress. Definitions and concepts: Deposit accounts are any liability account accepting customer funds repayable on demand or at maturity, protected (wholly or partly) by deposit insurance, they include transaction and non-transaction deposit accounts, for example: Checking/demand, savings, time/term deposit accounts, pensions. This is a core indicator in the IMF Financial Access Survey which collects financial access and usage indicators from 192 economies, for a number of financial institution types, enabling cross-country comparisons and benchmarking (https://data.imf.org/en/datasets/IMF.STA:FAS). Data requirements: Core-banking extracts listing unique account numbers, product codes, opening/closing dates, ownership type, currency, and last-activity timestamp. Limitations and considerations: Multiple accounts per person: high counts do not always equal high inclusion; adults often hold several accounts across banks—complement with unique account holders where possible. Dormancy rules: inconsistent activity windows distort cross-bank and cross-country comparisons; transparent “active” definitions are critical. Platform fragmentation: fintech wallets and neo-bank accounts may sit outside traditional bank reporting unless supervisory scope has expanded. Regulatory/reporting lags: real-time inclusion initiatives can outpace quarterly reporting cycles, delaying visibility of rapid shifts.

column4: Value (outstanding balances) of deposit accounts
column5: This indicator totals the outstanding balances—principal plus accrued but unpaid interest—across all active deposit accounts held at regulated financial institutions at a given reporting date. The figure reveals the size of the banking system’s core funding base, the stock of household and MSME sector savings, and the portion of the money supply sitting in deposit form among these sectors. A rising balance can reflect healthy income growth, successful financial-inclusion efforts, flight-to-safety behaviour, or accommodative monetary policy; a sharp decline may foreshadow liquidity stress, disintermediation into higher-yield instruments, or confidence shocks. Supervisors track the metric to test funding-gap ratios, calibrate deposit-insurance funds, and monitor the transmission of interest-rate moves to retail savers. Definitions and concepts: Outstanding balance: book value of customer liabilities on the reporting date, including accrued interest but excluding yet-to-post interest for the current period. Deposit types: demand/current, savings, time/fixed-term, notice, and negotiable order of withdrawal (NOW) accounts. Some jurisdictions also include e-money float ring-fenced in banks. Gross vs. net of reserve requirements: analyses should specify whether statutory reserve deductions have been netted out. Segmentation: resident vs. non-resident, retail vs. wholesale, insured vs. uninsured—each slice carries different run-off characteristics in a stress scenario. Data requirements: End-of-day core-banking ledger extracts with account number, product code, currency, balance, and customer sector. Mapping tables to consolidate subsidiaries and eliminate interbank or affiliate deposits. FX rates for translating foreign-currency accounts into a common reporting currency. Historical time series to assess growth trends and seasonality. Limitations and considerations: 4 Multiple counting: interbank placements and pass-through agent balances can inflate totals if not stripped out. FX volatility: large foreign-currency books can distort trends when exchange rates swing; constant-currency views help. Dormant or legally blocked funds: balances in frozen or deceased-estate accounts add to the stock but are not immediately withdrawable. Seasonality: corporate tax dates and bonus seasons cause predictable spikes and dips—use moving averages for structural analysis. Inflation-adjusted perspective: nominal growth may overstate real savings if consumer-price inflation is high. Derivable indicators: Average balance per deposit account.

column5: An aggregate measure of uptake of credit (loans) from financial institutions. When expressed as a share of the population, or in per capita terms, it is a measure of the prevalence of borrowing. Definitions and concepts: Borrowers refers to resident individuals or MSMEs that have obtained any type of credit from financial institutions. Individuals or MSMEs are counted as one borrower, irrespective of the number of loan accounts held. Data requirements: Unique borrowers with an open loan account at the end of a specific period (e.g. month, quarter or year.); For computing borrowers per capita or percent of adults that borrow from financial institutions, need total adult population (official count from census or estimates from national statistics agency). Limitations and considerations: If individuals are using loans from multiple financial institutions,  sector or system-wide aggregates, may count the same borrower more than once and therefore overstate the number of unique borrowers unless a unique national ID can be used to track individual borrowers across institutions. Additional requirements and/or operations for key disaggregations:  (A) By type of credit: For each unique borrower, a list of open loan accounts  at the end of a specific period (e.g. month, quarter or year). From this list, obtain the number of open loan accounts for each mutually exclusive credit type category relevant to the local context  (e.g. mortgage, credit card, personal loan, other revolving credit, etc), with a 0 if loan from category is not in use. The percentage of borrowers using at least one loan account for each credit category can then be computed.  (B) By loan size: The objective here is to assign all unique borrowers to a reduced set of loan size categories, for example the percentage of borrowers with loan sizes between (a) 0-10 USD, (b) 10-50 USD, (c) 50-100 USD, (d) 100-1000 USD, (e) 1000+ USD. Granular data or data system that can produce (1) A list of all active unique loans disbursed during a specific period of time, detailing the size (in currency units) of the loan disbursed, (2) Loan-level data should be linkable to a unique customer ID in order to examine all the loans that are currently active per borrower. The loan-level list can be aggregated to a borrower-level list by computing the average loan size per borrower; (C) By interest rate bands: This segmentations provides a summary of the distribution of borrowers by the interest rates attached to their loans, for a specific financial institution or the wider financial system, and require granular data or data system to produce: (1) A list of all active unique loans disbursed during a specific period of time, detailing the  interest rate (APR), (2) Loan-level data should be linkable to a unique customer ID in order to identify all the loans that are currently active per borrower. The loan-level list can be aggregated to a borrower-level list by computing the average APR per borrower (potentially using a weighted average using the loan size as the weight); (D) By credit type: This segmentation can provide measures of the relative prevalence of usage of broad credit types in the financial system.  This segmentation requires that for each unique borrower, a list of open loan accounts  at the end of a specific period (e.g. month, quarter or year) with additional detail available on the number of open loan accounts for each mutually exclusive credit type category relevant to the local context  (e.g. mortgage, credit card, personal loan, other revolving credit, etc), with a 0 if loan from category is not in use. The percentage of borrowers using at least one loan account for each credit category can then be computed.

column5:
Tracks the extent to which households—rather than institutions—participate in capital-market activity. Supervisors, exchanges, and policymakers follow the metric because a broad retail base diversifies funding sources, deepens market liquidity, and helps democratise wealth creation, yet it can also heighten conduct-risk and volatility when inexperienced investors herd into speculative assets. Sudden surges (e.g., during low-rate or “meme-stock” periods) may strain market infrastructure and prompt reviews of disclosure, leverage caps, and investor-protection rules. Definitions and concepts: Retail investor: a natural person trading on their own account; excludes professional clients and qualified counterparties under MiFID II, and often excludes high-net-worth individuals who meet professional criteria. Head-count measure – unique retail accounts or individuals registered with brokers/central depositories. Activity measure – percentage of total equity or ETF turnover, order count, or IPO allocation attributable to retail. Penetration rate – retail investor head-count ÷ adult population (or working-age population). Demographic segmentation: age, gender, income, and digital-channel uptake reveal inclusiveness and potential vulnerability pockets. Data requirements: Brokerage and trading-platform account registries (deduplicated for multi-broker relationships). Exchange order-flow tagging (retail vs. institutional) captured via participant codes or regulatory client identifiers.
Central Securities Depository (CSD) shareholder lists for direct-holding models. Investor surveys to gauge unrecorded indirect holdings (mutual funds, pension wrappers). Population statistics for penetration calculations. Limitations and considerations: Double-counting & fragmentation: individuals often hold multiple brokerage accounts; robust deduplication or probabilistic matching is needed.
Indirect exposure: retail ownership via funds is sizeable yet invisible in brokerage data, understating true household market exposure.
Data-protection barriers: privacy laws can restrict sharing of client-level identifiers, complicating cross-broker aggregation.
Market-cycle sensitivity: retail trading volumes are highly pro-cyclical; comparing absolute numbers across bull and bear markets can mislead without normalising for volatility.
Regulatory taxonomy differences: what qualifies as “professional” under EU rules may still be “retail” in emerging-market regimes, hindering cross-country benchmarking.

column4: Average cost of receiving and sending remittances
column5: Remittances are an important source of external financing in many countries around the world and support the well-being of migrant families as well as broader development as remittances provide greater opportunities, for savings, consumption and investment. Lowering the transaction costs of remittances matters because it means greater savings for remitters or more income for receiving family members. This indicator measures the financial cost of sending and receiving remittances using the country's financial insfrastructure and can be benchmarked against international averages, for example using the World Bank's remittance prices worldwide reports (https://remittanceprices.worldbank.org). Definitions and concepts: Money remittances are payment services where funds are received from a payer, without any payment accounts being created in the name of the payer or the payee, for the sole purpose of transferring a corresponding amount to a payee or to another institution offering payment services that is acting on behalf of the payee, and/or where such funds are received on behalf of and made available to the payee. These could be inflow transactions into an account, but many remittances will not land into accounts, but rather be withdrawn in cash via a money remitter, a mobile money agent or a bank branch (Committe on Payment and Settlement Systems red book: https://www.bis.org/cpmi/glossary_030301.pdf?). Data requirements: This indicator can be constructed using current listed prices or data already being reported to regulators to identify, for example, the cost of sending and receiving USD 200 by for each remittance service provider type (Bank, Money transfer operators, Mobile money operators, Post Offices) and for a specified set of remittance corridors that make up the dominant share of remittance corrditors. A simple average can be used (e.g. the average cost of sending 200 USD across all regulated banks) or weighting the listed prices by the volume or value of transactions flowing through each corridor if that data is available by reporting institution. Alternatively, this indicators can be constructed using transaction-level data to identify all remittance transactions made by customers that have been executed during a specific period of time, and taking an overall average or a weighted average by remittance corridor . This indicator is usually expressed as percentage of the value of the remittance being sent or received.

column5: A measure of the typical flow of funds behavior in savings accounts over a specific period of time. Overlaying the geographic distribution of transaction accounts on the geographic distribution of cash circulation can help to better understand the demand for and use of accounts. Definitions and concepts: Transaction accounts are broadly defined as an account held with a bank or other authorised and/or regulated service provider (including a non-bank) which can be used to make and receive payments. Transaction accounts can be further differentiated into deposit transaction accounts and e-money accounts, including mobile money accounts. While the overall supply of cash is determined by monetary policy that influences the level of currency in circulation, demand for cash concerns how the population chooses to spread currency across different activities, including (1) legal payments, (2) cash savings and (3) other transactions involving cash for use abroad, corruption or tax avoidance (https://www.imf.org/en/Publications/WP/Issues/2023/03/17/Measurement-and-Use-of-Cash-by-Half-the-Worlds-Population-531077). The demand for cash can be proxied by the aggregate volume of cash withdrawals. Inactive (or dormant) accounts refers to an account that has not been used to conduct transactions (e.g. deposits, withdrawals, transfers) over a long period of time prior to a specific reference date (e.g. one year). Passive transactions such as interest deposits are usually excluded. Data requirements: (1) List of inactive transaction accounts geo-located to the residence of the account owner at a primary or secondary subnational administrative area, (2) Proxy for demand for cash: E.g.  total cash withdrawals over a specified period for each administrative unit at the sleected sub-national level, (3) Total adult population (or surface area) at selected subnational administrative area. This indicator requires first computing the intensity of cash circulation in each subnational area in per-capita or km2 terms and defining a threshold above which the area is considered to have a high density of access points. The percentage of inactive accounts in subnational areas at or above the density threshold can then be computed.

Data requirements: (1) List of transaction accounts geo-located to the residence of the account owner at a primary or secondary subnational administrative area, (2) Proxy for demand for cash: E.g.  total cash withdrawals over a specified period for each administrative unit at the sleected sub-national level,  (3) Total adult population (or surface area) for each administrative unit at the selected subnational level. This indicator requires first computing the density of cash access points per subnational area in per-capita or km2 terms and defining a threshold above which the area is considered to have a high density of access points. column4: Volume and value of credit operations in the total financial sector portfolio
column5:
This indicator captures the breadth of formal lending with two perspectives: the number of credit contracts (volume) and their aggregate outstanding balance (value) across all regulated financial-service providers—commercial banks, development banks, credit cooperatives, microfinance institutions, finance companies, and regulated fintech lenders. Tracking it offers a panoramic view of credit intermediation, enabling supervisors to (i) gauge financial deepening, (ii) assess systemic leverage, (iii) monitor shifts in portfolio composition (e.g., rise of consumer or SME lending), and (iv) feed macro-prudential stress tests and monetary-policy models. Sharp expansions may indicate rapid financial inclusion or, conversely, overheating; contractions can herald credit crunches that dampen growth. Definitions and concepts: Credit operation – any legally binding loan, line of credit, hire-purchase, lease, or other receivable on the balance sheet of a regulated lender. Off-balance-sheet commitments (e.g., undrawn credit lines, guarantees) are usually excluded or reported separately. Volume (count): unique loan contracts outstanding at the reporting date; renewals/extensions count as new operations if a fresh contract is signed.
Value (stock): gross carrying amount before provisions, converted to a common currency for consolidation. Segmentation by sector (household, corporate, government), product type, currency, and residual maturity enriches analysis. Regulated FSPs – entities licensed and supervised under banking, cooperative, or specialized-credit legislation; shadow lenders fall outside scope unless specifically captured.Data requirements: Supervisory returns or call-reports detailing loan-book balances and contract count by institution and product. Standardised product and sector taxononies to avoid double counting. FX rates for translating foreign-currency portfolios. Institution identifiers to consolidate groups and branches. Historical series for seasonality and growth-rate calculations. Limitations and considerations: Coverage gaps: Unregulated peer-to-peer, informal lenders, and trade credit remain invisible, understating true credit supply. Double counting: Syndicated loans and on-lending between regulated entities can inflate aggregates unless netted. Valuation differences: IFRS amortised-cost figures versus local-GAAP gross amounts may hinder inter-institution comparability; harmonised reporting templates are essential. FX volatility: Currency swings affect value trends; analysts should present both nominal and constant-currency series. Contract granularity: Large corporate facilities can dwarf thousands of microloans—pairing volume and value prevents misinterpretation. Interpretation therefore benefits from complementary indicators (loan-to-GDP ratio, sectoral growth rates, NPLs) to paint a balanced picture of credit-market health and systemic risk.

column5: Tracking over-indebtedness gives authorities an early warning of systemic stress: when large segments of borrowers can’t meet their obligations, loan-loss provisions, bank solvency, and overall financial stability come under pressure. It also highlights consumer-protection gaps—persistent debt burdens signal predatory lending or inadequate affordability assessments—allowing regulators to calibrate prudential rules and market-conduct supervision to prevent crises before they materialize. This particular indicator that identifies borrowers at risk of overindebtedness was develeoped by the Central Bank of Brazil: https://www.bcb.gov.br/content/cidadaniafinanceira/documentos_cidadania/serie_cidadania/serie_cidadania_financeira_8_endividamento_risco_2ed.pdf ad https://www.researchgate.net/publication/376634051_Risky_Indebtedness_Behavior_Impacts_on_Financial_Preparation_for_Retirement_and_Perceived_Financial_Well-Being and is a composite of four component indicator as described below. Definitions and concepts: A borrower is flagged as being in "risky indebtedness" when any two of the following four criteria are met: (1) Has defaulted on credit installments, that is, has had payment delays of more than 90 days in meeting credit obligations, (2) Monthly income devoted to debt-service payments exceeds 50 percent, (3) Has simultaneous exposure to the following forms of credit: overdraft, unsecured personal loan, and revolving credit card debt, (4) Monthly disposable income (after debt-service payments) that falls below the poverty line. Data requirements: List of unique borrowers; Full loan level credit (repayment) history linkable to each unique borrower; Personal income. Limitations and considerations: Generating this indicator at the system level requires a unique national ID in order to match loans from all regulated FSPs to unique borrowers. The indicator also requires access to income data, which may be available in some cases from tax authorities or other government agencies. Derivable indicators: Percent of borrowers in risky indebtendess; Percent of adults in risky indebtedness.

column4: % of total topline revenue attributable to unsecured credit operations and interest and non-interest revenue proportions
column5:
This indicator captures the total income that a lending institution earns from unsecured credit products—credit cards, personal instalment loans, overdrafts, payday and buy-now-pay-later (BNPL) facilities—over a reporting period. Because unsecured lending is typically high-yield and high-risk, tracking its revenue helps supervisors and management understand how much of the institution’s top line depends on products that are more sensitive to economic downturns, job-market shocks and aggressive competition. A rising share can boost short-term profitability, but it may also presage higher future credit losses and conduct-risk concerns if underwriting standards slip. Definitions and concepts: Unsecured credit – loans that are not backed by collateral; repayment relies on the borrower’s cash flow and creditworthiness.
Revenue components – Interest income (accrued and collected) from outstanding balances. Fee income: annual fees, origination fees, late-payment charges, interchange on card transactions, BNPL merchant discount rates. Net insurance or payment-protection premiums (if bundled) may be included subject to local accounting rules.
Revenue share metric: Unsecured-credit revenue ÷ Total lending revenue expresses concentration risk. Risk-adjusted yield – revenue net of credit-loss provisions gives a clearer view of economic profitability. Data requirements: Product-level general-ledger extracts segregating interest, fees and other income. Loan-level flags identifying collateral status (secured vs. unsecured). Average daily or month-end balances to compute effective yields. Associated credit-loss provisions and write-offs for risk-adjusted analysis. Limitations and considerations: Mixed products: Some personal loans are partially secured (e.g., salary-linked) or carry optional collateral; clear taxonomy is essential. Fee recognition rules: Capitalised origination fees amortised under effective-interest-rate (EIR) accounting may blur timing comparisons across banks or jurisdictions. Regulatory caps: Interest-rate or fee ceilings (e.g., usury limits) affect revenue potential and comparability. Promotional pricing: Introductory 0 % card offers or BNPL “pay-in-4” models generate deferred revenue; headline figures may understate future income. Economic cyclicality: Unsecured-credit revenue can fall sharply in recessions as balances contract and charge-offs rise; pairing with delinquency and provision metrics is crucial for a full risk-return picture.

column4: Premiums ceded to reinsurers as % of claims paid by reinsurers and reinsurance commissions
column5:
The cost of reinsurance indicator quantifies the price an insurer pays to transfer part of its underwriting risk to reinsurers. Tracked as either an absolute expense or as a ratio—most often Reinsurance premium ceded ÷ Gross premiums written (GPW)—it shows how much earnings capacity the company surrenders for balance-sheet protection. Rising costs may stem from hardening global reinsurance markets, higher catastrophe exposures, deteriorating loss experience or weakened cedant credit quality. Supervisors and rating agencies watch the metric because excessive reliance on expensive cover can compress margins, while under-spending may leave the insurer over-exposed to shocks. Definitions and concepts: Reinsurance premium ceded: contractual payments (net of commissions) made to reinsurers for proportional (quota-share, surplus) or non-proportional (excess-of-loss, stop-loss) treaties, booked at treaty inception. Net cost of reinsurance: ceded premium minus ceding commission plus profit-commission adjustments and reinstatement premiums. Cost ratio variants:
Ceded-premium ratio—ceded premium ÷ GPW (gross view).
Net cost ratio—(ceded premium – commissions) ÷ Net premiums written (NPW). Market cycle: “soft” markets feature ample capacity and lower prices; “hard” markets follow major loss years, tightening terms and pushing up the indicator. Data requirements: Treaty schedules detailing ceded premium, ceding commissions, profit-commission formulas, reinstatement terms and capacity limits. Gross and net premium registers by line of business for denominator consistency. Historical loss data and catastrophe-model outputs to link pricing shifts to risk profile. Currency breakdown to isolate FX effects on multi-currency programmes. Limitations and considerations: Treaty mix effects: A pivot from quota-share to excess-of-loss lowers ceded premiums but might raise reinstatement costs in a bad year; headline ratios should be analysed alongside retention curves. Timing mismatches: Premiums are typically paid up-front, while recoveries occur post-loss, so annual cost ratios can spike in growth years and dip after large events. Ceding commissions: High fronted commissions on quota-share deals can obscure the true net cost; analysts should focus on post-commission cash flows. Counter-party credit risk: Cheap cover from low-rated reinsurers may understate economic cost once collateral requirements or credit-risk capital charges are considered.Regulatory capital offsets: Some jurisdictions grant solvency credit for risk transfer only if treaties meet strict risk-transfer tests; fail-points can turn apparent cost savings into capital drains. Evaluated over time and in tandem with retention ratios, loss experience and solvency coverage, the cost-of-reinsurance indicator reveals whether an insurer’s risk-transfer strategy is prudent, affordable and sustainable.

column4: % of gross written premium that is net (as a measure of the level of dependency on reinsurance)
column5:
Also known as the net retention ratio or risk retention ratio, this indicator shows the proportion of insurance risk an insurer keeps on its own balance sheet after ceding portions to reinsurers. It is usually expressed as Net premiums written ÷ Gross premiums written, or, for claims, Net incurred claims ÷ Gross incurred claims. A high ratio signals greater self-reliance (and potentially higher earnings volatility), while a low ratio points to heavy dependence on reinsurance, which may reduce earnings swings but create counter-party and availability risks. Supervisors monitor the metric to ensure that ceded volumes are commensurate with the insurer’s capital strength, product mix, and risk appetite, and to detect excessive outward reinsurance that might mask under-capitalisation. Definitions and concepts: Gross premiums written (GPW): Total premium income before reinsurance ceded.
Net premiums written (NPW): GPW minus premiums ceded plus reinsurance recoveries on ceded unearned premiums.
Retention strategy: the targeted share of each risk or line that the company keeps. Common variations include quota-share, surplus, excess-of-loss, and stop-loss treaties, each affecting retention differently across severity and frequency layers. Counter-party credit risk: reliance on reinsurers introduces the need to assess reinsurer financial strength and collateral arrangements. Data requirements: Line-of-business breakdown of GPW and NPW (or claims) for the period. Details of outward reinsurance treaties (type, attachment points, limits, reinstatements). Reinsurer credit ratings and collateral held (letters of credit, trusts, funds withheld). Historical loss triangles net and gross to analyse retention across cohorts. Limitations and considerations: Treaty structure nuance: A single headline ratio can conceal materially different risk profiles—e.g., low retention on catastrophe layers but high retention on attritional losses. Accounting timing: Premium recognition and profit-commission adjustments can distort period ratios, especially for multi-year treaties. Counter-party concentration: A low dependency ratio is only as strong as the reinsurer panel; high concentration risk may offset the benefits of ceding. Regulatory arbitrage: Aggressive use of finite-risk or fronting arrangements can lower apparent retention without true risk transfer; regulators scrutinise such structures under risk-transfer tests (e.g., Solvency II Article 208). Analysts therefore pair the retention ratio with treaty-level stress tests, reinsurer credit assessments, and solvency coverage ratios to gain a holistic view of an insurer’s reinsurance dependency and residual risk.

column4: Level of technical provisions to cover actuarial liabilities
column5:
Technical provisions represent the present-value estimate of all future cash outflows that an insurer expects to incur on already-written policies, including claims not yet reported (IBNR), claims reported but not settled, and future policyholder benefits. Adequate provisions are the cornerstone of insurance solvency: if reserves are understated, an insurer may appear profitable while silently eroding its ability to meet policy obligations and regulatory capital requirements. Definitions & concepts: Technical provisions comprise two main blocks: Best-Estimate Liabilities (BEL), the probability-weighted expected value of future cash flows (claims, benefits, expenses) discounted using risk-free or prescribed curves; and Risk Margins, an additional amount reflecting the cost of holding capital to run off the liabilities (Solvency II) or a prudential margin (IFRS 17, LAT). Within BEL, Life insurers separate mathematical reserves and participation features, while Non-Life insurers distinguish Unearned Premium Reserves, Outstanding Claims Reserves, and IBNR. Discounting, inflation assumptions, lapse behaviour, and reinsurance recoverables are critical modelling inputs. Data requirements: Policy-level datasets: inception date, coverage term, sum assured, premium schedule, embedded options. Claims triangles: paid and incurred data by accident year/underwriting year for run-off analysis. Economic parameters: risk-free yield curve, inflation indices, currency basis. Experience studies: mortality, morbidity, lapse, and expense analyses to calibrate best-estimate assumptions.
Reinsurance treaties: cessions, limits, and expected recoveries. Limitations and considerations: Model risk: Heavy reliance on actuarial projections; small assumption shifts (e.g., longevity, claims inflation) can materially move liabilities. Interest-rate sensitivity: Low-rate environments inflate discounted liabilities, especially for long-duration life contracts. Regulatory divergence: Solvency II, ICS, and local GAAP use different discount curves, risk margins, and contract boundaries, hindering cross-country comparisons. Management discretion: Profit-sharing, early-settlement strategies, or reserve releases can smooth earnings but obscure underlying risk trends. Robust governance—peer reviews, back-testing, and sensitivity analysis—is essential to ensure technical provisions faithfully capture the insurer’s true obligations.

column4: Total regulatory capital relative as % of risk weighted assets (RWAs)
column5:
CAR (often synonymous with Total Capital Ratio) shows the sum of Tier 1 and Tier 2 capital relative to RWA. It captures the full loss-absorbing cushion, including subordinated debt, and underpins Pillar 1 minimums plus buffers. Definitions and concepts: Tier 2 instruments must be dated subordinated debt or loan-loss reserves with at least 5-year maturities and explicit loss-absorption characteristics. Regulatory buffers (capital conservation, counter-cyclical, systemic) sit on top of the 8% minimum. Data requirements: Full breakdown of regulatory capital components, RWA by risk type, capital deductions, buffer add-ons, and transitional arrangements. Limitations & considerations: Inclusion of Tier 2 can mask deteriorating core equity quality.
National transitional rules (phase-ins/outs) make international comparisons tricky. Internal-model RWA variability remains a live policy concern; hence supervisors also track leverage ratio as a back-stop.

column4: Stability/volatility of retail deposits (deposit stickness, deposit stability, deposit flows)
column5:
The deposit-stability (or deposit-volatility) indicator assesses how predictable a bank’s funding base is by tracking the fluctuation and “stickiness” of customer deposits over time. Sudden, correlated outflows—whether triggered by market rumours, rate competition or digital-bank runs—can force the bank to liquidate assets at fire-sale prices or draw on emergency facilities. Regulators therefore monitor deposit volatility alongside liquidity ratios to judge an institution’s ability to withstand funding shocks and to calibrate run-off assumptions in stress tests and the Liquidity Coverage Ratio (LCR). Definitions & concepts: Core / stable deposits: retail or SME balances judged unlikely to flee under stress; often defined by balance size, relationship depth, and whether the account is transactional (“operational”) rather than rate-sensitive. Volatility metrics: standard deviation of daily balances divided by the mean (coefficient of variation), maximum one-day net outflow over a look-back window, or elasticity (beta) to market rates.
Deposit concentration: Herfindahl-Hirschman Index or share held by top N customers, a key driver of volatility. Behavioural run-off factors: Basel assigns 3%–10% to stable retail deposits and ≥40% to non-operational corporate deposits. Data requirements: High-frequency (daily or intraday) deposit-balance time series, tagged by customer type, product, and currency. Interest-rate history to estimate betas. Customer identifiers for relationship tenure, cross-selling, and concentration analysis. Event logs for promotional campaigns or pricing changes that may distort normal behaviour. Limitations and considerations: Window-dressing: balances can spike at quarter-end to flatter liquidity metrics.
Segmentation judgement: mis-classifying rate-sensitive deposits as “stable” understates risk. Digital-channel dynamics: mobile-app withdrawals can accelerate run speed beyond historical norms; backward-looking volatility measures may understate future risk.
Macro factors: deposit flight often correlates across banks during systemic stress, reducing diversification benefits. Hence supervisors pair volatility indicators with scenario-based outflow assumptions, contingency-funding plans, and qualitative assessments of customer behaviour to obtain a robust view of funding resilience.

column4: Effciency ratio
column5: Indicates operating efficiency by comparing non-interest expenses to operating income. Lower ratios signal better cost control, a key driver of sustainable profitability, especially in low-margin environments. Definitions & concepts – Efficiency Ratio = Operating expenses ÷ (Net interest income + Non-interest income). Some variants exclude litigation or restructuring charges. Limitations and considerations: Cost cuts that impair risk management or customer service may improve the ratio temporarily but raise long-run risks. Cross-country comparisons should adjust for labour cost levels and digitalisation stages. One-off income (e.g., asset sales) can distort the denominator.

column4: Interest margin to gross income
column5: Also called Net Interest Margin (NIM), it captures the spread between interest income on earning assets and interest expense on funding, scaled by average earning assets. It reflects balance-sheet pricing strategy and interest-rate risk management. Definitions and concepts: NIM = (Interest income – Interest expense) ÷ Average earning assets. “Earning assets” exclude non-interest-bearing reserves. Data requirements: Detailed interest income/expense breakdowns, granular asset/liability repricing buckets to diagnose margin compression. Limitations and considerations: Rising rates may widen NIM for asset-sensitive banks but compress it for liability-sensitive ones—static measures mask this asymmetry. Non-performing loans (NPLs) carried at interest accrual can artificially boost NIM if not reversed.

column4: Large exposures as % of total capital
column5: Tracks a bank’s credit exposures to single counterparties or groups that exceed a threshold (typically 10% of eligible capital) and ensures none breach the regulatory cap (25% in Basel guidelines). Concentration risk is a major trigger of systemic failures. Definitions and concepts: Exposure includes on- and off-balance-sheet items after credit risk mitigation (CRM). Group of connected clients incorporates economic interdependence, not just legal ties. Data requirements: Counterparty-level exposure data, CRM adjustments, eligible capital base, and industry group classifications. Limitations & considerations: Defining economic interdependence requires judgment; under-aggregation understates concentration. Trades cleared through CCPs complicate exposure measurement. Rapid intraday build-ups can escape month-end reporting.

column5: Shows the share of highly liquid, unencumbered assets (cash, central-bank reserves, Level 1 HQLA) in relation to total assets or short-term liabilities. column4: Liquidity ratio
column5: The LCR tests whether a bank holds enough HQLA to survive a 30-day stress scenario; the Net Stable Funding Ratio (NSFR) evaluates one-year structural funding. Both curb excessive maturity transformation. Definitions and concepts: LCR = Stock of HQLA ÷ 30-day Net Cash Outflows ≥ 100%. NSFR = Available Stable Funding (ASF) ÷ Required Stable Funding (RSF) ≥ 100%. Risk-weighted factors apply to assets and funding sources. Data requirements: Contractual cash-flow schedules, behavioural deposit models, collateral eligibility maps, and stress runoff assumptions. Limitations and considerations: Behavioural modelling (e.g., retail deposit stickiness) is judgement-based and regulator-specific. Off-balance-sheet commitments add complexity. Both ratios are point-in-time; intramonth spikes in outflows may go unnoticed.

column4: Exposure to property
column5:
The property-to-capital ratio compares a bank’s aggregate exposure to the real-estate sector with the loss-absorbing capital available to absorb a housing-market shock. A high ratio indicates that a sizeable decline in property prices—or in borrowers’ repayment capacity—could wipe out a large share of the institution’s solvency buffer, amplifying systemic stress. Supervisors therefore use the metric to spot concentration risk, calibrate counter-cyclical capital buffers, and justify targeted underwriting limits. Definitions and concepts:  Property exposure: the on-balance-sheet book value of residential and commercial real-estate loans, loans secured by property under construction, and foreclosed real estate held for sale. Some jurisdictions add off-balance-sheet commitments (undrawn mortgage lines, guarantees) or direct equity investments in property companies.
Capital: usually Common Equity Tier 1 (CET1) or Total Regulatory Capital, net of deductions. Ratio formula: Total property exposure ÷ Capital × 100 %. Segmenting into Residential Property / Capital and Commercial Property / Capital reveals which market drives concentration. Data requirements:  Loan-level or granular portfolio data tagged by collateral type and purpose (owner-occupied, buy-to-let, office, retail, etc.). Valuation data for repossessed property and construction-in-progress. Quarterly or monthly regulatory capital figures, both transitional and fully-loaded. Memoranda items on undrawn commitments to capture pipeline risk. Limitations and considerations: Classification ambiguity: mixed-use or multi-purpose facilities can be mis-classified, blurring residential versus commercial signals. Collateral valuation lags: property values are often updated infrequently; rapid price swings may make exposures appear lower than market reality. Risk-weight heterogeneity: two banks with identical ratios may hold very different risk-weighted assets if one uses internal models with lower real-estate risk weights. Macroprudential overlays: caps on loan-to-income or loan-to-value ratios can mitigate vulnerability even when the indicator is high, so it should be analysed alongside underwriting quality, provisioning coverage, and stress-test results.
Used in trend and peer analysis, the property-to-capital ratio provides an early warning of over-concentration in real-estate lending and informs both micro-prudential and macro-prudential policy actions.

column4: Return on assets
column5:
ROA gauges how efficiently a bank turns every unit of assets under its control into net profit. Because banks are highly leveraged, asset efficiency is a clearer performance yard-stick than raw earnings, and supervisors watch for sudden drops that can foretell solvency stress. Definitions and concepts: ROA = Net income after tax ÷ Average total assets (opening + closing assets ÷ 2). “Total assets” must reflect IFRS 9 or equivalent classifications, with loan-loss allowances netted out. Data requirements: Audited income statement (net income) and balance-sheet totals at two balance-sheet dates, preferably quarterly to smooth seasonality. For cross-bank comparability, assets should be consolidated across subsidiaries. Limitations and considerations: ROA ignores off-balance-sheet exposures such as guarantees or derivatives.
Accounting choices (fair-value vs amortised cost, tax treatments) can distort comparability across jurisdictions. Short-term spikes may stem from one-off gains; trend analysis over several periods is essential. For fast-growing institutions, average assets can lag reality, overstating ROA.

column4: Return on equity
column5:
ROE indicates the earnings available to common shareholders per unit of book equity. Regulators use it as a sustainability check: chronically low risk-adjusted ROE can push banks toward excessive leverage in search of yield. Definitions and concepts: ROE = Net income attributable to ordinary shareholders ÷ Average shareholders’ equity. Equity here excludes AT1 instruments and revaluation reserves if not freely distributable. The DuPont decomposition (ROE = ROA × Asset-to-Equity leverage) links profitability to balance-sheet risk. Data requirements: Consolidated net income and shareholders’ equity from audited reports; interim data if high-frequency monitoring is required. Limitations and considerations: Mark-to-market swings in Other Comprehensive Income can mask underlying earnings power.
High ROE achieved through leverage may coincide with weak capital ratios. Comparing ROE across jurisdictions with different capital buffers or dividend payout rules needs caution.

column4: Number of suspicious transaction reports
column5: The indicator tallies the reports that banks, insurers, money-value transfer providers, and other reporting entities file with the national Financial Intelligence Unit (FIU) when they detect activity that may involve money-laundering, terrorism financing, sanctions evasion, or related predicate offences. A rising count can signal stronger detection systems and compliance awareness, while a sudden drop may hint at control weaknesses—or, conversely, that earlier over-reporting has been corrected. Policymakers use STR volumes, in combination with disposition data (e.g., investigations, prosecutions), to gauge the health of the Anti-Money Laundering/Combating the Financing of Terrorism (AML/CFT) regime and to allocate investigative resources. Definitions and concepts: Suspicious Transaction Report (STR): a mandatory report filed “as soon as practicable” when a transaction is known, suspected, or has reasonable grounds to be suspected of involving criminal proceeds or terrorist funds (FATF Rec. 20). Equivalent terms include Suspicious Activity Report (SAR) in the United States. Reporting entities: broadly, all institutions covered by the AML/CFT law (banks, securities firms, casinos, DNFBPs). Objective vs. subjective STRs: some jurisdictions distinguish automated threshold-based filings (objective) from analyst-driven filings (subjective), a useful nuance for interpreting volumes. Data requirements: FIU registry of incoming STRs, ideally tagged by date, reporting institution, sector, transaction channel, predicate crime category, and outcome (e.g., disseminated to law-enforcement); Denominator data: number of active reporting entities or total transactions to derive reporting intensity metrics (STRs per 1,000 accounts, etc.). Regulatory amendments or guidance notes that may affect reporting thresholds or definitions. Limitations and considerations: Volume ≠ effectiveness: high counts may reflect defensive “over-filing,” whereas low counts in high-risk sectors can signal under-reporting. Outcome metrics (cases initiated, assets restrained) are needed for a fuller picture. Sector mix effects: Expansion of reporting obligations (e.g., to virtual-asset service providers) can inflate year-on-year totals; trend analysis should adjust for coverage changes. Data quality: Duplicate submissions, incomplete narratives, or vague suspicion reasons hamper analysis and inflate reported numbers without real value. Confidentiality constraints: Detailed, institution-level STR data are usually restricted; aggregated figures may mask significant inter-bank variation. Used judiciously alongside risk assessments, supervisory findings, and law-enforcement outcomes, the number of STRs provides a vital—but not standalone—signal of AML/CFT system performance.

column3: Systematic reporting to financial intelligence unit/office (FIU)
column4: Number of transactions reported (excluding suspicious transaction reports) to FIU
column5:
This indicator counts all objective anti-money-laundering (AML) disclosures that reporting institutions file with the FIU other than Suspicious Transaction Reports (STRs)—for example Cash / Large-Value Transaction Reports (CTRs/LCTRs), Cross-Border Currency Reports (CBCRs), Electronic Funds Transfer Reports (EFTIs), and threshold-based casino or dealer filings. Tracking the volume highlights how much potentially high-risk activity flows through the regulated system, tests the reach and effectiveness of automated monitoring engines, and helps the FIU size analytical workloads and allocate investigative resources. Sharp changes may flag shifts in cash-based commerce, regulatory threshold tweaks, or system-integration problems at reporting entities. When combined with STR counts and outcome statistics, this indicator offers a comprehensive perspective on the preventive arm of the AML/CFT framework and the evolving risk landscape of cash and cross-border fund flows. Definitions and concepts: Objective reports: filings triggered automatically when a transaction exceeds a statutory threshold or meets a predefined typology—irrespective of suspicion. Common examples: CTR / LCTR – cash deposits, withdrawals, or exchanges ≥ (e.g.) USD 10 000. CBCR – physical cross-border movements of currency or bearer negotiable instruments above a set limit. EFTI / International Funds Transfer Instruction (IFTI) – cross-border wire transfers over a threshold. Casino / Dealer reports – chip buy-ins or precious-metal trades over a threshold. Reporting entities: all AML-obliged institutions—banks, MSBs, securities firms, DNFBPs—must file within the statutory deadline. Denominator metrics (optional): total transactions processed or number of active customers, enabling intensity ratios. Data requirements: FIU registry of objective-report filings with unique identifiers, filing date, reporting institution, transaction value, currency, channel, and report type. Systems logs from core banking, cash counters, payment switches, and customs to validate completeness. Limitations and considerations: Threshold drift:  Policy-driven threshold changes can spike or suppress counts—trend analysis must normalise for rule changes. False positives / fragmentation: One multipart transaction may create several filings (e.g., split deposits), inflating totals; deduplication logic improves accuracy. Coverage gaps: Informal money-value transfer services outside the regulatory perimeter are invisible, understating systemic cash movements.
Data-quality variance: Missing customer identifiers or incorrect codes hinder FIU analytics; robust validation routines are essential. Workload vs. value: High volumes can overwhelm FIU resources; pairing the indicator with conversion metrics (reports that trigger investigations, prosecutions, asset seizures) provides a fuller view of effectiveness.

column4: Tier 1 regulatory capital as % of risk weighted assets (RWAs)
column5:
The Tier 1 ratio shows the core loss-absorbing capital (CET1 + AT1) relative to risk-weighted assets (RWA). It is a cornerstone of Basel III solvency standards and a trigger point for supervisory intervention. Definitions and concepts: Tier 1 capital comprises common equity tier 1 (CET1) plus additional tier 1 (perpetual, non-cumulative instruments). RWA adjust asset values for credit, market, and operational risk weights.
Data requirements: Regulatory capital composition tables, risk-weighting calculations or model outputs, deductions (goodwill, DTAs), and supervisory approvals for internal models. Limitations and considerations: Internal-ratings-based (IRB) banks may report lower RWA than standardized peers, inflating comparability. National discretion (e.g., mortgage risk weights) can create uneven playing fields.
AT1 coupon cancellation risk means two banks with identical ratios may differ in resilience.

column4: Exposure to market risk (value volatility in the trading book)
column5: VaR estimates the maximum potential trading-book loss over a specified horizon at a given confidence level (e.g., one-day 99%). It informs market-risk capital and limits. Definitions and concepts: Parametric, historical, and Monte Carlo VaR methodologies vary in how they model distribution tails. Basel permits a 97.5% CVaR (expected shortfall) for FRTB; many banks still report traditional VaR in parallel. Data requirements: Time series of risk-factor prices, correlations, volatilities, portfolio position data, and back-testing results. Limitations and considerations: VaR is not additive across portfolios and ignores extreme tail events beyond the confidence level (“black swans”). Assumes normal market conditions; during crises, correlations spike and VaR underestimates risk. Requires robust data history; structural breaks reduce predictive power.
